												There's not a lot to say about Van Helsing, either good or bad. Despite the pleasing graphics, witty banter and good voice acting, Van Helsing tends to meander on a bit. That said, it's not an especially long game, and the time-tested ARPG system of challenging combat balanced out with a need for loot that works for your given playstyle, makes Van Helsing reasonably addicting anyhow. Posted: June 6, 2013
												If you want more from your regular hack-n-slash RPG than just... well, hack and slash monsters and demons; that is, if you also want some good story, beautiful looking landscapes, and a dense and unique atmosphere, then this one could be for you, since it possesses all these properties. But... who knows for sure? Maybe you want even more than that these days to be convinced, something new from an old genre. Let's see...Well...- How about a good - and we mean GOOD - soundtrack, that perfectly - and we mean PERFECTLY - matches with that said unique atmosphere? Yes?Check.- How about some really nice voice acting (most of the time, at least), with European accent and all? Ok? You know van Helsing's environment is Europe, right? You remember Bram Stocker? Without google, that is. I hope so.Ok, then, check.- How about some little puzzles with ancient, sacred pagan objects in the middle of some frightening bog, infested with demonic beasts trying to tear your hat - and your head inside it - mercilessly apart? How about fighting some blood-thirsty, hellish fiends that jump over you out of the blue, cause you're trying to retrieve some legendary, holy, long hidden relic? How about answering some riddles - yes, we said riddles - from enigmatic NPC's, to which a wrong answer could mean a quick, but no less painful death?Check those.- How about some funny moments that will put a smile on your foolish face: funny references to famous games, books, movies, and characters every now and then?Check this too.You want all that, don't you? Man, then this game is definitely for you! Just grab it now, cause it have it all, you fool!"Then it is perfect?" you could ask. You know, no game is perfect."So what's wrong with this one?" Well... hum... let's see... Ah, yes! Some skills, mainly the melee ones, aren't flashy enough. Yes. That's it. They could be more flashy. Why not? Well, they are useful, they enhance your survivability, and they are fun to use and kill stuff with, but... not enough colourful lights onto the melee skills. The ranged skills are somewhat flashy, but the melee, not so much...Well...If that's not enough to keep you away from the game, then...But, to be fair, there's actually one more issue. Some people who played on easy or normal difficulty and rushed the main quest complained that the game is too short. They say 15 hours or so is too short. But... what game on easy or normal is not too short nowadays. After all, one one-shots almost anything stupid enough to cross one's way on those "difficulties". Our answer: stop playing on normal, you brainless cowards, and play games as they are supposed to be played! Your idiotic utterances do nothing but spread misinformation over the world of gaming!Just play The Incredible Adventures of van Helsing in no other difficulty than Heroic, which is the highest one, and you're on for a fantastic and rewarding adventure that will keep you busy for a good while.One more thing. Incredibly, this is an indie game, developed by some little known, small Hungarian group, and it's supposed to be the first part of a trilogy. So, give them your support for their making of this brilliant gem, if you like the game, and show them your interest in the subsequent ones.

Posted: May 28, 2013
												Van Helsing is an arpg fantasy game set in the not too distant past. You play as the son of Van Helsing and, like your father, you have a variety of spells, ranged weapons, and blade weapons at your disposal. The story isn’t great, but it’s also no worse than the stories in other arpgs. Van Helsing, the ghostly companion, and a few other notable characters have decent voice work, but the rest of the cast is plagued by lines likely composed by the programmers themselves. Most of the locations are graphically pleasing, but some appear slightly blurry (idk why???). The-game play is smooth and responsive; the enemies vary in aesthetics and behavior; and the progression system is elaborate and rewarding. Overall, the game at its core is great, but bugs, glitches, and oversights (see comment section) compound to drastically ravage the overall experience. The Incredible Adventures Of Van Helsing: 7.5 / 10.0

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Slice up werewolves, then shoot the faces off frog demons. Fun. Appropriately challenging on normal difficulty. Don't try to start on hard (like this guy)! If you seek a challenging experience, start with normal and you'll find challenging enemies soon.It's well written. The voice acting feels right. Characters are interesting. Katarina, your ghostly battle-buddy, chimes in with witty comments or advice at the right times, and these feel welcome (no Navi syndrome here). There's plenty of humor to be found in NPCs. There are plenty of nods to folklore and even historical figures (e.g., Elizabeth Bathory).Graphics and animations look satisfying enough, as of Summer, 2014 standards. Really, nobody should expect triple A visuals from an indie title. It does come pretty close.This hack 'n slash dungeon crawler takes some old elements of the genre: health/mana potions, stat points and skill trees, hordes of enemies, ect., and adds a few new elements. Not too many, though. This is still a dungeon crawler lootfest. Fans of the genre will be pleased. As for shortcomings, I have thus far found minor ones. Few bugs. Pathfinding is a minor issue at times. There is only one class in the default game (2 more with DLCs). Granted, this one class has plenty of customization; you can build Van Helsing mostly how you'd like. You can also customize Katarina's skills and stats, allowing her to cover weaknesses in your build, or to prop up your strengths even further. However, there is no significant tutorial system except a handful of control blurbs. As for how to build your character, you have to figure that out. Thankfully, there are plenty of respeccing opportunities; just pay an NPC some gold.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												I picked this up a few weeks ago on sale and so far, have greatly enjoyed it.  It's an action rpg with surprisingly good character chemsitry and voice acting.  The interactions between the protagonist and his ghostly companion are well acted and entertaining.  The companion helps in combat, either through a ranged form, melee form, or passive form that grants you 10% damage resistance.The skill system (for the primary Hunter character) is divided into 4 parts.  Melee, Ranged, Tricks, and Auras.  Melee and Ranged are self-explanatory.  Tricks give you spells that don't require mana but have a timer, that range from healing, to cloning your ghost, to ramming through your enemies.  Auras grant you passive improvements to your character.  One aspect I really enjoy of the skill system is the ability to upgrade your ghostly companion.  You can spec her to have skills that passively benefit you (such as increased magic find or defense) or enhance her damage and survivabilty. Combat is a bit diferent in that you can enhance your skills with adrenaline.  Each skill offers 3 different side-grades that you can enhance your attack with all at once (e.g., +30% damage, +10% damage resistance, +10% length) or dump all of your adrenaline into one for maximum effect (e.g, +90% damage).  The combinations are interesting and even the early skills remain viable throughout the game.  Combat can be irratating because you are constantly being swarmed by gangs of monsters, so the focus tends to be more on crowd control than anything else.  As you progress through the story, some monsters are downright brutal and can kill you very quickly if you are not careful.  The story is on par for the genre and the setting, while appropriately grim, isn't anything spectacular.  There are a few bugs here and there, so be forewarned.  At times, the game will hang, which can be really annoying.  Generally it clears up but I have had to force-quit on at least one occassion.With the vanilla pack, there is only the Hunter class.  While you can spec Van Helsing with all sorts of skills, if you want a pure magic based or technology based character, you will have to pay for them in separate DLC. Bottom line:  If you like action RPGS, you will like The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing.  It's not perfect, but I think it has enough charm to help it stand out in the crowd.

												THIS GAME IMO:-incredible graphics. (For notebook or low spec pc, dont worry ! (not like some other games i've played)-Quests aren't boring and most of them are fun/challeging)-the game is easy as hell on normal and easy settings, becomes normal on hard, and challenging on heroic(which is the one i recommend).-The lore of this game is addictive and hell creative.-Has some steam-punk features which is very well made and adapted to this game.-It is a little repetitive but no exausting.-Quest have multiple ending, so the outcome might be different based on your choice.Conclusion i would give this game a 9/10.The gameplay is very good, nice, smooth and envolving music, good voice acting, great quests, and satisfactory lore(excellent beggining and ending).

												Played this game a bit now, got it on sale, but honestly it would have been worth it even if it wasn't. The game maps are expansive, detailed, and fun to run through. However, the fix to this was simple enough, load the game from its binary (/steamapps/common/<gameloc>) and set back to full screen, and everything was back up and running.Another issue was being unable to change camera angles, being unable to do so, was a bit off-putting but certainly not enough to keep me from enjoying the rest of the gameplay.As it stands I do highly recommend this game, as it is highly enjoyable and by and large well designed – overall, it was certainly an enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												I adore this style of gaming and the fantasy theme calls to something within me. So when the game on sale I quickly clicked 'buy' and began my quest as a Van Helsing. So, what did I think (and still do as I have by no means completed it)?I FREAKING LOVE this game! The theme and back-drop to the game is spot on as you wade through hordes of all varieties of mythical monstrosities.  Graphically, the game delivers well and is pleasing to the eye. The voice acting for Van Helsing and Katarina (DLC) is superb. Really well done! The banter between them adds depth to their characters and is a real treat to hear. The musical score/sound effects are brilliant too and again adds to the immersion.Character customisation is varied and gives much choice to the three classes to choose from. Each gives a different way of combating the horrors that await.Loot... oh the loot. Much is to be gathered and acquired as one would expect from a game such as this. The game is fun to play, even more so with friends (or my dad in my case) but beware, the game (for me) can get addictive. I always feel I need to keep playing just to get that next item that will boost my DPS or to see what new enemies are lurking around the corner.For all its pros there are unfortunately some cons. Certain shrines cannot be activated, instead once clicked causes your character to wander trying to find it even though it's right in front of them, denying you an XP/DMG boost. With the Arcane Mechanic class (which I play and love burning monsters with) when I click over an enemy to attack, he wonders off, not knowing where it is. A pathing issue with this and the shrines I'm thinking.The worst issue (for me) is no matter how long I play for, be it five minutes or five hours, upon exiting the game my PC shows a CPU temperature warning. My PC is not old and boasts some high-end hardware so I was quite surprised when the message popped up. Never before have I seen such a message other than playing Skyrim (with mods and graphical enhancements) for almost an entire day straight, which is justified. These issues I have are not enough for me to stop playing, but it would be nice if they were resolved.9/10

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing from developer NeocoreGames is a action role-playing game, in the vein of the Diablo series. While the title's price would suggest it might be a bargain bin title, the actual truth is far different as the game contains an extensive amount of content that is polished and entertaining. While the game's scope might not be as large as other titles in the genre, the content easily consumes hours upon hours of time as gaining new loot and slaying monsters of all sorts is an addictive experience.The game's narrative has players partaking on a journey as the son of famous monster slayer Van Helsing along with a ghost companion named Lady Katarina.  Together you will explore  various locales in the gothic and magic-infused kingdom of Borgovia. Settings range from forests crawling with werewolves to dark city streets controlled by mechanized armies of soldiers. Each chapter provides the player with a hub base or town to buy and sell supplies as well as plenty of quests that require the aid of a monster slayer. While some quests incorporate puzzles and even tower defense elements, the majority of objectives have players slaying endless amounts of monsters.Much of the narrative's enjoyment can be contributed to the great dialogue exchanges between Helsing and Lady Katarina. One-liners and an assortment of sarcastic comments from each make both of them lovable characters throughout the game's narrative. It's not often in action role-playing games such as Diablo or Torchlight that the player's character has much of a personality other than their style in battle. It's a refreshing change that not just the main characters have great personalities in the game, but also much of the characters that players meet in the game's world.Veterans of the genre will immediately feel at home as standard mechanics for the genre are all in place. As you would expect players earn experience from slaying enemies and completing quests for use in upgrading their character's assortment of skills. The skill system is split into melee combat, ranged combat, and magical abilities, each of which contain both active and passive skills that can be leveled. Lady Katarina also contains her own assortment of skills that not only strengthen her combat and defense, but also abilities that aid Helsing both inside and outside of battles.Aside from completing a near endless amount of quests, players can spend their time crafting better weapons and equipment as well as upgrading their base's defenses in the game's later stages. As Helsing's role is a monster slayer, he is skilled in both melee and ranged combat enabling him to switch instantly between a sword and rifle or pistols.As with most action role-playing games, the major draw of battling enemies and completing quests is the drive to acquire more loot. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing delivers up to a degree as the game contains a wide assortment of weapons and gear to loot from fallen monsters. The one lacking area with the loot system is limited customization of the protagonist's appearance as most armor and clothing items differ only slightly from each other. The game doesn't disappoint with its visuals as all of the elements ranging from environments to monsters are both highly-detailed and polished. The variety of monsters remain satisfying through the narrative's course with players confronting enemies from werewolves to magical-based, mechanized soldiers. While the sound effects from exploding enemies to the howls of werewolves aren't anything special, the game's soundtrack sets the tone perfectly with an assortment of memorable tracks. The soundtrack works especially well with various environments in the game's world, which results in the perfect atmosphere for slaying monsters and collecting loot.It's not often that games are released containing such an extensive amount of content in addition to being highly-polished for such a low price. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing offers players both a satisfying and addictive experience over the course of its lengthy adventure. . The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a must-buy for fans of slaying monsters and acquiring masses of loot.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Diablo-style isometric games seem to be enjoying a rennaissance since Torchlight and in spite (or maybe because) of how abysmally shallow Diablo 3 was. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is another entrant in this category, but one that smartly does a few things differently than its contemporaries. I won't go as far as to say that it's necessarily better than my current fave, Torchlight 2, but it's DIFFERENT. And it does it well. If you've never played one of these, Torchlight (1 or 2) might be a better introduction, but for the money they're asking Van Helsing will do fine.Since I already made the Torchlight 2 comparison, I should stick with it. Gameplay is largely similar, but Van Helsing amps the utility of the companion character. This is a sharp-tongued ghost whose banter with Van Helsing brings in a smattering of levity in sometimes not so appropriate circumstances. While she has a bit less depth than the player character she brings her own skill trees, stats and gear to taylor her to your needs. Which is to say, for my heavy hitting ranged attacker I've specced her to be a 'tank', but she can set up for added damage or support as well. On top of that, Van Helsing has a set of aura skills which further refine the relationship between the two characters. This alone allows for a number of gameplay variety. Add to this a tower defense style subgame for even more fun and two DLC character classes for even more variety and you have a game that seldomly feels boring.But the real star to me is the setting of Van Helsing. Taking cues from the Hugh Jackman movie of the same name and not being afraid to reach deeply into a cliché vault, the game presents a turn of the century world full of fairy tale monsters, mythical beasts and mad scientists replete with clockwork soldiers and mutant troopers. As hinted at above the game often doesn't take itself too seriously and that is ultimately what makes the mixture work. While not as thought through as the backdrop of, say, Dishonored, it's a nice departure from the generic fantasy tropes you get in most any form of RPG to this day.The game is far from perfect, still plagued by bugs and balance issues and the way scenery fades out so as to not obstruct your view (or pops back in) can be pretty jarring. But for the price it's being sold at I find that perfectly acceptable. It's not like it's the 3rd part in an acclaimed series from a purported top studio that is a dumbed down version of its predecessor, it doesn't force you to be always online, has no attached con artistry like a cash auction house... you probably get the idea. For what it is, it's a rocking game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing from developer NeocoreGames is a action role-playing game, in the vein of the Diablo series. While the title's price would suggest it might be a bargain bin title, the actual truth is far different as the game contains an extensive amount of content that is polished and entertaining. While the game's scope might not be as large as other titles in the genre, the content easily consumes hours upon hours of time as gaining new loot and slaying monsters of all sorts is an addictive experience.The game's narrative has players partaking on a journey as the son of famous monster slayer Van Helsing along with a ghost companion named Lady Katarina.  Together you will explore  various locales in the gothic and magic-infused kingdom of Borgovia. Settings range from forests crawling with werewolves to dark city streets controlled by mechanized armies of soldiers. Each chapter provides the player with a hub base or town to buy and sell supplies as well as plenty of quests that require the aid of a monster slayer. While some quests incorporate puzzles and even tower defense elements, the majority of objectives have players slaying endless amounts of monsters.Much of the narrative's enjoyment can be contributed to the great dialogue exchanges between Helsing and Lady Katarina. One-liners and an assortment of sarcastic comments from each make both of them lovable characters throughout the game's narrative. It's not often in action role-playing games such as Diablo or Torchlight that the player's character has much of a personality other than their style in battle. It's a refreshing change that not just the main characters have great personalities in the game, but also much of the characters that players meet in the game's world.Veterans of the genre will immediately feel at home as standard mechanics for the genre are all in place. As you would expect players earn experience from slaying enemies and completing quests for use in upgrading their character's assortment of skills. The skill system is split into melee combat, ranged combat, and magical abilities, each of which contain both active and passive skills that can be leveled. Lady Katarina also contains her own assortment of skills that not only strengthen her combat and defense, but also abilities that aid Helsing both inside and outside of battles.Aside from completing a near endless amount of quests, players can spend their time crafting better weapons and equipment as well as upgrading their base's defenses in the game's later stages. As Helsing's role is a monster slayer, he is skilled in both melee and ranged combat enabling him to switch instantly between a sword and rifle or pistols.As with most action role-playing games, the major draw of battling enemies and completing quests is the drive to acquire more loot. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing delivers up to a degree as the game contains a wide assortment of weapons and gear to loot from fallen monsters. The one lacking area with the loot system is limited customization of the protagonist's appearance as most armor and clothing items differ only slightly from each other. The game doesn't disappoint with its visuals as all of the elements ranging from environments to monsters are both highly-detailed and polished. The variety of monsters remain satisfying through the narrative's course with players confronting enemies from werewolves to magical-based, mechanized soldiers. While the sound effects from exploding enemies to the howls of werewolves aren't anything special, the game's soundtrack sets the tone perfectly with an assortment of memorable tracks. The soundtrack works especially well with various environments in the game's world, which results in the perfect atmosphere for slaying monsters and collecting loot.It's not often that games are released containing such an extensive amount of content in addition to being highly-polished for such a low price. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing offers players both a satisfying and addictive experience over the course of its lengthy adventure. . The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a must-buy for fans of slaying monsters and acquiring masses of loot.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												I really love ARPGs and the way they play, that said I absolutely despise this game.I'm reccomending it because despite its major flaws it's still playable and has a great atmosphere, although you're very likely to get fed up with it and uninstall.I'll start this off by saying that all of its problems are caused by too many enemies at once, this game goes completely overboard in that department.Area of effect damage is a requirement, anything that does single target is next to useless here. The further you go into the game the larger the mob of enemies it constantly throws at you becomes, you can't even pick them off from a distance because chances are that the entire mob is going to react and come after you, and another thing to note is that your ranged attacks do not go over enemies which means all those high damage ranged enemies are safe behind the giant wall in your face. And on top of that some of them can heal other enemies, so you HAVE to kill them first.There is a perk that makes you atheral when your health runs out, you're going to find yourself getting a lot of useage out of that one. Along with that you're going to find yourself needing to heal constantly, so cooldown reduction is an absolute must so you can use heal often.I cannot even fathom playing the game class due the fact that there are enemies who drain your mana beyond faster than you can regenerate it even with mana potions, and this doesn't stop being a pain if with other classes, because all of your skills cost mana to use except your default skills.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Well what can I say about this game. It's fun, it's not that long thankfully because the game can get redundant pretty quickly, especially if you have Unlimited Spawn selected like I did the first time I tried and gave up. It was only after a couple of years I learnd about that option (didn't see it the first time in the options) so I went back to play it and I actually enjoyed it much better.This is what I would call a low impact game. For me, something to play to relax and not worry about multiplayer chaos like CS-GO. If you like Neverwinter Nights, it's something like the same style of gameplay. There is a lot to learn about the game but unfortunately I didn't encourage myself to learn the spells and tricks that the player can use in the game. I played straight up, in your face combat. The only thing that I found that was a bit out of character of Van Helsing is that you are not fighting many werewolves. There are not vampires and classic monsters that we all know and love, though the story is based on mechanical monsters aspect. The beginning of the game does give you that vampire hunter feeling, but it doesn't last long. Still, if you are looking for a game to pass the time, this would be good for you.As always, I recommend on buying it on a discount. $5 on a Winter sale I think I got it.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												IAVH is a fun, solid game with a few problems that keeps it from rising above a 8/10.The Good:Now with 3 character classes, you are no longer stuck with one guy that does everything half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Classes are still rather plain being the melee, magic and ranged stereotypes. The skills the classes feature are mostly unique, with a small selection of them being repeats of skills other classes have.The perk system is fun and adds a unique feel to your character. Katarina the ghost WAS a♥♥♥♥♥♥poor addition. With all the patches and full dlc I feel she is actually worth putting into combat now. Having her tank damage and aggro for me has been rather effective, rather than before when she was dying in 5 hits while being built tanky. Loot drop rate is still really high, but the loot is much better and I find myself playing just to find the next drop. I've not used the glory system yet but it looks like a decent way to keep higher levels interested in their build.The Bad:Multiplayer community is tiny. You will rarely see more than 25 games during peak time, and as little as none during others. Rarely will the games be hosted in the US region. What this means is basically if you're in the US, you need friends to play this game with. Relying on random people from the internet is merely not enough. If you can get past the glaring lag, there's still many more issues that need to be addressed. As such, I can only recommend that if you pickup IAVH for the multiplayer, get your friends to do so as well, or don't get it at all. There are also technical problems with the graphical engine. Running IAVH on full settings produces BSOD extremely often. Although entirely capable of running the game maxed, I can't because of blue screens. Games released both before and after have no problem being maxed without technical problems. This is something that can be fixed, but there's no guarantee that it will be.Ultimately, I enjoy the game and I think you would too. If you must have multiplayer, but do not have any PC gaming buddies to play with, I'd pass over this one, random internet denizens will just not be enough.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												This game is a real bitter sweet one. It is both amazingly creative and the most lazy game ever.So lets play the sweet and bitter game. For everything good there is almost something equally bad about this game.This game has some REALLY cool monsters. If you have never seen Teslapunk before you are in for a fun suprise, however it is overshadowed by the excessive use of them and constant combat. I played on the middle difficulty and towards the end there are enemys that just take forever to put down, and they arnt even the ones that do good damage either so you end up kiting one enemy for almost a full minute even if you killed everything else.The Enviroments look amazing. Statues, monuments, temples and even the sewer level look very nice. However the plot makes it so you have to go back and do parts of the map over again to progress the story so you start to sigh as you do a level over again.The voice acting is very well done. The problem are the constant meme, references and pop culture get rather tiring cause you have heard them all before in something with a far better plot. Speaking of the plot the game starts out really interesting then kind of tapers off and then crashes and burns towards the end. I think the best way to describe this is the final boss.When you encounter him you have your confrontations something like this:"We finally have you! Why did you do all this?" "Why? Because I am evil! This is what I do. Your the good guy I am the bad guy." Granted there are tons of 007 references and many other tropy things but that just sort of killed the illusion there had been a plot for me.Overall this game really has no replay value and I cant really say I would reccomend buying it because its just another Diablo style clone.

												The Complete Pack is not complete, they didn't include the Pre-order DLCs, instead they expect us to buy it directly from them.so that is already a big minus, because it can already be called as a fraud.Pro :- Graphics are good enough.- 360 controller are supported (for those that love to use gamepad)Con :- Can't easily switch between gamepad and K+M- Combat are not fluid enough- Poor Optimization.- The game somehow doesn't want to recognize the DLCs that i got from complete pack.- Story is crap- Complete pack is a fraud because not all DLCs are included.- Gameplay felt like a chore- Max Level is only 30, for an ARPG that is a big fail (i'm guessing they want to do Borderland style of level cap, but the game failed to take off).- There is still a lot of bugs (ex : i often had my lady katarina stuck a lot of time, and she can't seem to free herself).Conclusion :If you like chores, then this game is for you, otherwise stay away, but if you really dying to play an ARPG, then this game is decent enough.Overall i gave this game : 5.7 out of 10Reason : some of the cons can be fixed, if the dev willing to do it, but since it seems the Dev have started making the sequel,  chances are high that they are gonna abandon this game.@Dev : if you make a complete pack, include all DLCs, the "Complete Pack" = all DLCs included, and why not sell those preorder DLC in steam store too ? why hold it back ? this game is decent, but its nothing special.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												This is a very mediocre "Diablo" like game.  It borrows mechanics from many games and does them all poorly.  Leveling up isn't very interesting because all your skills ramp down so quickly.  For example, skill point 1 gets you +5% damage (meh).  Point 2 brings it to 7.5%, point 3 bring it to 8.5%, etc...  All skills work like this, so by the time you are level 20 or so, you have all the skills you want and leveling up just seems pointless.The combat isn't interesing either.  You can buff your powers by spending "rage" which you generate while fighting. Yet the same thing applies and the effects arn't worth the effort.  There are better games out there.   Titian Quest Gold,  Torchlight 1 and 2, and most certainly Diablo 3.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing played like any other hack and slash game on the market.  Really nothing new about it.  The game play and progression trees are both just fine.  The story was fairly interesting but again nothing really remarkable.  I enjoyed my first few hours of gameplay but became somewhat bored with the game and set it aside for awhile.  Recently I returned to the game in the hopes of finishing the story and being able to get a full impression of it.  Alas, it was not to be...This game quickly shows it's true colors if you visit the forums for the game.  Many of the quests are broken and need to be reset using console commands to complete them.  This is just lazy on the part of the Dev. team who created a sequel and couldn't be bothered to fix the first one.  You'll also find many people have had problems getting the game to even launch...anyway from my personal experience the game will no longer resume story when I click "resume story" just a wonderful crash to desktop.  After spending a few hours verifying the game cache on steam and even going as far as reinstalling the game and following all steps mentioned on the forums to fix the game.  I discovered that my save file was corrupted.  I can start a new character but at this point I'm far to♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off and dissapointed in the developer for not fixing all the bugs to the original game before making a sequel that will probably be just as bug ridden.Bottom Line__________________ AVOID THIS GAME.  There are numerous hack & slash games on the market that are far better so don't bother with this game it will just dissapoint and frustrate you.  It's quite unfortunate because I really wanted to like this game and was even planning on getting the sequel after finishing the first.  I doubt that will happen now.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Enjoyable action RPG with many of the same features you would find in Diablo style games.  If you're looking for a good single player story, character customization options, and all around monster slaughtering goodness then this won't disappoint.I suggest getting the full pack that includes all of the DLC as it opens up a number of new classes, features for all of the classes, some new quests/areas, and equipment.  If you've enjoyed Diablo, Diablo 2, Diablo 3, Path of Exile, or any of the other similar ARPG's this is a good one for you!Note, this is not a strong multiplayer game or something you can expect to invest a lot of time into.  You'll enjoy the story, level a character or two, and then be done with it forever.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												A rock solid Action RPG which borrows the right elements from its competitors and mixes it into something unique.The fighting switches fluently from ranged to close combat complete with different skill sets with the press of a button and can be quite taxing at times - even on normal - with hordes of canon fodder, champions and unique monster all with different and often synergizing abilities. To easen it up a little we have a battling companion at our side who doubles as a packmule (best known from Torchlight).Character development is fairly shallow with a handful of active and passive skills in the melee and ranged trees, some spells and some auras to choose from. While each skill has a couple of passive and activated power-ups, it's still nothing too dazzling and hard hitting combinations are obvious. Our ghost companion meanwhile just provides a couple of passive buffs like higher damage or resistance.The world is handmade and thoughtfully designed, offering beatifuly scenaries packed with interactions and secrets which invite you to explore the world off the main path and rewards you for it. The downside is, that it has very little replay value and infact after you're done with the story, you can either play a couple of challenges to find new loot and get some passive boni upon completion or start a New Game+ with your character against leveling monsters whereas you're left at the level cap.There are a few things to be wary of, though:Multiplayer seems still broken, some people experience plot stopping bugs (which thankfully are addressed very quickly and can be fixed ingame) and the game is badly optimized. Even with the recommended speccs, you'll experience input lag and frame rate drops which will ruin the experience at times.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												A supriseingly good action RPG with a setting distinct from most fantasy games with steampunk mixed with mythology barrowed from Universal monster movies and eastern Europe. Fast pace with huge groups of well animinated and imagiative monsters. Somewhat like Diablo 2 in it's loot system. Character building is deep and flexable though not every ability feels equally useful. The addition of a follower that can sell unneeded items for you and buy healing potions is nice without being new, though the flexbility offered by the ghostly companion is nice. Tower-defense like sections break things up nicely and don't overstay their welcome.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Van Helsing is definately not a game without flaws, but for the most part they all seem to have counterpoints.  The lack of meaningful character customization is off-set by the tightly focused story-driven nature of the game.  The static maps kill replayability a bit, but also allow for better designed set pieces. The skill system is a shallow ocean- giving the illusion of depth but in order to be viable you really need to pick a set of a couple skills and pour all your points into them. I can't speak for the ranged tree as I primarily played melee, your choices are somewhat limited given the crazy mob density that this game throws at you- which, don't get me wrong, was definately a positive- but it means that you need abilities that will kill a lot of guys at once in order to keep from being overwhelmed or whittling guys down at a choke point one at a time for hours on end. Then, while you're doing that you realize you could just be Earthquaking all the guys in a row and be done 10 times quicker.In short, Van Helsing is worth the price of admission, especially if you can catch it on sale.  It's a fun, short romp that does what it advertises, just don't expect a Diablo/Torchlight/Path of Exile killer.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												An all around wondeful game.It has a dark steampunk kind of atmosphere, with a decent story and good replayability, especially since two new characters came out.I wholeheartedly recommend getting the complete pack as it's a great value.The gameplay is really good, the maps are big open wide environments, except some areas seem a bit too crowded and you risk getting overwhelmed easily.The tower defense mechanics don't seem forced on and are really fun to do.The only flaw for me is that you are restricted to 2 spells only(with a recent patch you can use the 4 bottom slots as well,but still having a nice hotbar would've been great!).Play this with a friend(or two) and you have a great game at a great price!

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												This is a very mediocre "Diablo" like game.  It borrows mechanics from many games and does them all poorly.  Leveling up isn't very interesting because all your skills ramp down so quickly.  For example, skill point 1 gets you +5% damage (meh).  Point 2 brings it to 7.5%, point 3 bring it to 8.5%, etc...  All skills work like this, so by the time you are level 20 or so, you have all the skills you want and leveling up just seems pointless.The combat isn't interesing either.  You can buff your powers by spending "rage" which you generate while fighting. Yet the same thing applies and the effects arn't worth the effort.  There are better games out there.   Titian Quest Gold,  Torchlight 1 and 2, and most certainly Diablo 3.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												After finishing Torchlight 2 I wanted to play something that looks alike. Finally, I got this game at sale with some friends of mine. At first sight everything seemed to be great: lots of skills and branches, very helpful assistant Catherine that can also level-up and has different builds. The first negative impression came on the first location after the town. My friend couldn’t load. After several changes of lobby leader and re-launching the game, the problem was solved. Ok, sh*t happens, nevermind. After a few hours one of  the characters reached 12 lvl and 99% and then stopped gaining any experience. After re-launching the game its level was 12 and 50%. Okaaay, let’s go forward. We all were 13 lvl, killed a boss on the quest location and…a miracle! Two characters stayed lvl 13 and the third one became lvl 5! He got 21 skill point and was unable to put on any clothes above his 5th lvl. This time re-launching didn’t help us at all, so after this I’ve lost any wish to continue playing this “fascinating” masterpiece. We’ll see what developers got at The incredible adventures of Van Helsing Final Cut.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a Hack 'N' Slay RPG.You are Van Helsing, a monster hunter.On your site is a hot evil ghost called Katarina.You traveled into a region called Borgova.Something evil is happening there and you have to find out what it is.Your way leads you through cities, forests, caves and many more things just to find the person who is responsible for everything.The gameplay is nice. Its like other Hack 'N' Slays like Diablo or Torchlight but it has a dark steampunk touch.I really like the whole design of the game, beats Diablo and Torchlight in my opinion.There is an incredible amount of weapons and accessoires.The game has a typical level up system which gives you skillpoints everytime you level up.Some items are also only usable when having a certain level.Furthermore there are bonuses for finishing certain quests like killing 100 werewolves or whatever.You can choose some bonuses from time to time.Nearly everything is also supported by Katarina.The enemy varity is pretty much actually. There are several groups of enemies and those have always different levels.Masters are the most dangerous. There are also veterans and others.Also there are some bosses ingame.People in the world might give you quests from time to time, nothing special but gives you a lot of loot.Loot is the best about this game anyway. Its addicting collecting loot.The difficult is higher than usual I think, at least I died several times even with using healing mage and a lot of potions.I played on Normal. I personally skilled myself on far fight. Isnt easy though because the monster approach you very fast.The Graphics are good for a game of that sort, nothing special though.But I really liked the whole design especially of the forest.It will also run on older PCs.I also have to say that the music of the game is really nice.I read that there is a soundtrack avaiable, but only for the second game.Should include the music from the first game too, I read.The game also has some sort of Multiplayer, didnt looked into it until now though.It has Coop which is nice, I will probably try it sometime.I have to say that I didnt awaited a lot of this game but I really started to love it.Its addicting and has a interesting story and design.Definitely a good game for Hack 'N' Slay fans.I will probably buy the second game earlier or later.I will give the game 8/10 points.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												Having finished Van Helsing in Heroic Hardcore with melee orientated setup, I can only say that it has been a worthy and enjoyable fill to my Diablo 2 addiction. The Blue Blood DLC helped a lot to clear up later levels which previously I found too hard (completed it by only reaching lvl28). Single playthrough took about 35 hours completing about 75% of achievements (could have been higher but gave up on achievements after aiming for the "But they are so cute! one by not killing any Igors at all, until the very end when one died by accident having forgotten to switch Katarina to ethereal). Enjoyed the good graphics, very funny dialogue and a lot of action. My only disapointment was the let down felt once completed, with only a 30sec cinematic ending the game. TL;DR: I would highly recommend "The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing" to anyone that is a fan of Diablo 2 type of games or anyone looking for an action/ hack and slash rpg adventure.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Pros: - cheap- simple- sometimes looks okay- setting not entirely cloned from Diablo seriesCons:- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice acting- 20GB for barely anything- you can lag as the host- crashes sometimes- items seem hardly relevant, skills are 99% of the damage- characters' looks hardly ever change by more than just tiny bits- terrible pathfinding and level design from hell- large portions of the game (2/3 classes...) only in a DLC- no difficulty scaling. You can play on casual and still get onehits throughout the game, but most of the time you just hold RMB and wait til it's over.It's an okay-ish game in its price range that would have needed some polishing. It looks mostly budget or dated, but still takes a lot more performance than what you get for in return. Could have been more.

The first negative impression came on the first location after the town. My friend couldn’t load. After several changes of lobby leader and re-launching the game, the problem was solved. Ok, sh*t happens, nevermind. After a few hours one of  the characters reached 12 lvl and 99% and then stopped gaining any experience. After re-launching the game its level was 12 and 50%. Okaaay, let’s go forward. We all were 13 lvl, killed a boss on the quest location and…a miracle! Two characters stayed lvl 13 and the third one became lvl 5! He got 21 skill point and was unable to put on any clothes above his 5th lvl. This time re-launching didn’t help us at all, so after this I’ve lost any wish to continue playing this “fascinating” masterpiece. We’ll see what developers got at The incredible adventures of Van Helsing Final Cut.

Posted: November 25, 2013
The Incredible Adventures of Van HelsingRating: 7 / 10Fun Action-RPG in a nice and detailed steam-punk world. Maps are a bit big and pre-filled which makes the pace a bit slow as you cannot 'run' though these levels. Lots of interesting loot, lots of upgrade options for skills and abilities. Halfway an interesting twist as you have to defend and expand your hideout in a tower-defence like way. Shops could be better and the gameplay is a bit too linear for my taste. Still a big thumbs up for giving me a great time. (Not finished yet)

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												TL:DR : go play Diablo, Sacred, Marvel heroes, Titan Quest or PoE instead...Like others bad HnS games, they try too hard to be like Diablo, but different than Diablo, which generally means that they fail at both. Van Helsing makes no exception. It feels like a bad gimmick made by people who don't understand the basic gameplay features of an HnS game :- stupid "skill power up" system that makes you feel like you're using the two same skills over and over.- incredibly bad balancing. I tried to continue my first game ( normal mode ) near the end of the story after not playing for months and just got killed again and again by a pack of werewolves, just outside the exit of the lair... Thought I wasn't used to the game anymore so I started a new character in casual, and the mobs are either a pice of cake and don't do any damage, or they are ultra resistants and kill me and Katarina in seconds...- fighting mechanics suck. It's either hold down the click until everyone is dead, or move, attack, move, attack, move, attack ad nauseam to avoid damage.- loot suck. Why is there blue and gold items if they are always worst than white ? Also most of the time I find items several levels over me and I can't use them, so they just clutter my inventory or I sell them, and then I'm undergeared.- we can find loot for DLC classes that we don't even have bought...- inventory is ridiculously small for a game with so much loot ( fortunately you can send Katarina to sell stuff, but having to fill her inventory every 5 min and then wait for her return is boring ).- the town portal brings you back to the city but you can't go back to where you came from... what's the point ? Those guys don't even know what a town portal is made for...- armor design is bland and barely noticeable anyway.- NOT ENOUGH RAGE ! ( due to the stupid "auto power up" option... who the hell got this idea ? )- the game randomly changes my resolution when I start.- Vsync either doesn't work or is deactivated after alt-tabbing.- the character gets stuck in invisible walls, and can't move when there are too many mobs on the screen. Thanksfully we can move with WASD, but even that sometimes doesn't help.- Katarina is completely useless even as a tank with all points in body/melee.- 99% of the mobs attack in close combat, so you get ganked if you play melee, and if you play ranged once Kat is out of combat...- the game made my PC totally freeze, had to hard reboot.- SPOILER : the final boss is lame and you don't even kill him, he just flees... all this for nothing.- and then you unlock the "neverending" mode, where mobs are big HP bags, you get one shot several times in a row by mobs that pull you toward them and stun you, you kinda don't get much XP and there is no reason to suffer through the whole game a second time anyway. Loot is still crap by the way.On the positive side :- the character moves fast enough- graphics and music are nice ( characters are ugly though )- lots of mobs- eastern Europe folklore- i like Katarina's sassy dialogue and the duo works well, even if Van Helsing doesn't have much personality for a hero... would be totally bland without Kat.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												Let me start by saying I haven't beaten this game yet, but at level 26, I'm far enough in to give a review. I'm going to list pros and cons and then expand upon them down below. I'm not really going to touch upon the story all that much.Pros:Story is alright (nothing special, but it's better than most of what you'll find these days)Nice level designGame provides a challenge (both a pro and a con, see below)Katarina is a pretty cool character Varied enemiesCons:Framerate tanks to below 30 in some areas if you can believe thatAI partner is uselessGame provides a challenge (both a pro and a con, see below)Very lame skilltree as a mageVoice acting is pretty lame (Van Helsing isn't too bad, Katarina is hit or miss and the rest of the NPC's are pretty bad)Combat is boringTo start off, you play as Van Helsing's son (yea, THE Van Helsing). Something is wrong in this city that your father cleared out years ago and you must save the day. You are accompanied by Katarina, a ghost who is bound to serve your family. She is your partner in combat and can either be a melee or ranged specialist. She also levels up and has her own skill tree.This game does a few things right. Level design is something you will notice upon loading up a new area. The areas you prod around in are generally large and look pretty good. So far I've been through a small village, forested areas, a mine, a sewer, secret laboratories, The Ink (kind of a take on The Fade from Dragon Age) and a big city. Each location has impressed me thus far. Also a plus is Katarina herself. Trudging around the game by yourself would get pretty boring. Her presence, combined with the banter she has with Van Helsing is decent enough to where the game doesn't feel so grindy. Also a plus are the various types of enemies with different abilities. The game groups up different enemies constantly, and some of the battles can be very tough.Unfortunately, for every thing this game does right, there's two things it does wrong. Firstly, the game tanks to below 30 FPS in certain areas. This is on a 4770k with 2x 7870 Myst Editions. It's happened in two areas so far. It's not in one little spot on the map, either. The framerate keeps tanking throughout the whole area. If I leave the area, I start getting great frames again. As soon as I go back in, it tanks again. I guess those areas were just very poorly optimized. Next, combat is weak at best. I am playing as a mage, and combat doesn't feel good at all. None of the spells you can unlock feel good/forceful, and some of them require you to keep clicking your mouse button to charge up a spell, draw a line on the screen for a wall of fire, etc. This wouldn't be such a problem if you weren't fighting 20+ enemies at a time, and if your AI partner was competent. Katarina is utterly useless. I thought setting her up as a melee specialist would let her tank damage and draw enemy aggro as I hit them from range with my spells. Not quite. Enemies run right by her as if she's not even there and book it straight at me. This leads to every battle turning into a StraCraft-esque kite-fest, which gets old, fast. To make matters worse, you cannot command Katarina to attack a target. You can setup behaviors for her where she'll attack your target, the weakest target, the most vulnerable target, or the target that is attacking you (which is all of them), but you can't click on a target for her to attack. This means you have to aggro the enemies yourself. Not a problem if you're playing a sword-wielding badass, but as a mage it's terrible.As I mentioned the game provides a challenge. Some of that is due to good enemy design, but most of it is artificial. Katarina being terrible and enemies running straight for you are the two biggest culprits of that artificial difficulty. Also contributing to this are some of the enemy groups you will run into. For instance, there is a part in a laboratory where you run into 6-7 Champion versions (the enemies have different tiers, Champion being the toughest) of this one enemy that has the ability to raise undead, trap you temporarily, form a temporary barrier, lay down an AOE poison spell, and an AOE spell that just drains your health as soon as you step into it. The fight went something like this. Step into area, trigger aggro on the 6-7 enemies, they cast raise undead to the 50+ rat-like corpses on the ground, use barrier so I can't go anywhere, use trap to hold me in place, cast poison or the other AOE spell on me while the rat things beat on me and I'm dead in seconds. I died 10+ times in that one place, due solely to how cheap the enemies were. This type of nonsense happens every now and again.When it comes down to it, I can't recommend this game. If only the combat matched the pretty visuals...

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Pros: - cheap- simple- sometimes looks okay- setting not entirely cloned from Diablo seriesCons:- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice acting- 20GB for barely anything- you can lag as the host- crashes sometimes- items seem hardly relevant, skills are 99% of the damage- characters' looks hardly ever change by more than just tiny bits- terrible pathfinding and level design from hell- large portions of the game (2/3 classes...) only in a DLC- no difficulty scaling. You can play on casual and still get onehits throughout the game, but most of the time you just hold RMB and wait til it's over.It's an okay-ish game in its price range that would have needed some polishing. It looks mostly budget or dated, but still takes a lot more performance than what you get for in return. Could have been more.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25
												The game is all right, but it doesn't do anything new. Feels like a cheap version of TL2, which in turn feels like a cheap version of D2.Maybe I just picked the wrong class playing as a hunter, but combat was extremely boring. Every monster felt identical since the best way to beat them was to fire, back away. Fire, back away. From smallest rat all the way up to the final boss, that was how I killed the 11'533 monsters I had to get through to complete the game. Quantity over quality, is the name of the game here.And the worst part is that gear, skills and stats don't matter, because everything just scales. You'll never be exited about finding a new item or gaining a level.I played it through to the end because I wanted to know how it ended, but it wasn't worth it. There really isn't any story, and the combat just isn't fun.5/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												I'd like to say in advance, I LOVE Steampunk games, I LOVE Hack 'n Slash, but most of all, I LOVE Van Helsing. This game is, in many ways, a fantastic one. The behavioral settings on Lady Katarina are interesting and helpful, the loot system is ok, the music and environment are great, and the voice acting is one of the best in Indie gaming history. The Drawback, however, is in the actual "Hack 'n Slash" part. This games Combat is HORRIBLE. and the reasons are that, one, you hold still and sit there everytime you attack which is annoying for ranged players and downright punishing for melee players. The other problem with combat is the fact that the game attacks your targets for you, meaning I, a ranged player, cannot chose which guy I'm gunna shoot at. Instead the game is gunna make me shoot the wolf instead of the wolf handler, or the boss. So I don't get to chose my targets which hurt melee players even more, because, unless they are lucky, can't Dps the highest damage monster and are forced to sit there and take hits from all the guys while they are stuck hit that Fricking wolf that deals no damage whatsoever. So those are the problems with combat. Other problems include the lack of tutorial on how the inventory and level ups and as well as specail attacks work. It wasn't a glaring problem since I am a Dark Souls player and don't need my hand held, but it took me a frustrating 10 Mins to figure out how to equip better gear. My final qualm is this. Why do I need to set what percentage of health Katarina needs to be at before she is allowed to drink a health potion? Just... why? At first I didn't know what it was so I set it to the max and then gave Katarina some health potions. We get into a fight and she downed all five health potions like they were tick-tacks. She then was complaining about her lack of Health potions and i replied "Sweetheart, you drank those last five health potions at the speed of light. I'm not gunna give you anymore." So that sums up why a am not going to recommend this game. As much is I like it and had fun, the glaringly painful combat ruined what could have been a really great tribute to Steampunk Hack 'n Slashes.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												The game is fun, but not that much of a challenge in normal mode. I topped the Max level of 30 before I reached the end scene. There is a "crafting" system letting you upgrade weapons and armours with powerful attributes.The environments (maps) are beautiful but not seamless. You use portals to enter/exit each map.I kept my weapons and armour updated and maxed out my primary weapon skills as early as possible and played it through in 20 hours. The campaign wasn't that much of a challenge and the supposed anti climax when defeating the last boss was more like "what, was this all?"However, after playing the full campaign, a new mode is unlocked that gives more hardcore gaming.Overall, it gave me 20 hours of game play and after the campaign, you get bigger challenges.

number of helpful: 29 of 59 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Van Helsing gets a couple of things right: the atmosphere is great, the graphics look pretty good and remind me of Diablo 2. Having a companion who is always cracking jokes, usually at your expense is also entertaining, I thought the voice acting was done quite well.As an ARPG though, this game is a disapointment. The main campain is rather short, you can easily finish it in 10 hours. Unlike other ARPG's, there is no grinding for better items or skills since there are no areas where enemies respawn and you will have visited almost every part of every area once you finish the game the first time. There is no reason to revisit it since there is no new game+ either.The one aspect of the game that really interested me was the tower defense element. Unfortunately this is also a disappointment as it does not fit into the story well and seems more tacked on, not only that but there are only two short tower defense parts in the whole game and no way to do any optional missions at all.Multiplayer doesn't work well, I've read many reports of people experiencing bugs and I also had a couple of problems when I tried it, quests getting stuck and similar problems. Another problem is that when a person in your party starts a bug you are forced to join after 5 seconds, even if you are in a dialogue with an NPC.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												If you really enjoyed Diablo or those type of games, it's worth checking this game out. The developers obviously cared about their finished product.If you're on the fence or you do not enjoy those games, do not try this. The first half of the game is pretty enjoyable, but after a while you either get so specialized and good with your skills that you are ripping stuff apart or it just feels downright repetitive, although that may just be a hallmark of this type of game's combat system.It's about 15 hours long, give or take a few hours depending on how quickly you move through it and how thorough you are. I played the entire game single player, so perhaps multiplayer is a completely different experience. If you plan on playing this alone though, unless you're really in love with this type of game, do not purchase it.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11
Product received for free
												To preface this, I won this on steamgifts.com.It took me about 16 hours to play through the entire game, I found it to be a decent ARPG. The story was very blah, simple. It had a ton of action though, and plenty of different ways I could have built my character. I decided to take a brawn approach with my character (side note... I have been doing that a lot recently... my most recent Skyrim character has been brute force kinda guy and my couple newest DnD characters have been Barbarians). This maybe where I struggled a bit, as I tried to max/min the character to a bit but still tried to get as many achievements as I could. This could have definitely tainted my experience with the game.Overall, I think the game controlled great, never cheated me or anything of that nature, and definitely had a fluid nature. I absolutely adored the fact that I could send my ghost back to town and she would just sell all my crap loot without the need to stop play. I think that is something more ARPGs could handle better, is the amount of loot you attain. But with that being said, I never had that ah ha moment where I just felt like a badass that could slay anything in my path or that I really accomplished anything in general. That with its perceived that it had a shallow system of progression melee or range with a few different types of kickers with the perk system. That's why I would give it a 3/5 stars, but if you are looking for some loot grabbing, enemy smashing, you could go much worse than Van Helsing here.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												SNAPSHOTAn uninspired Diablo clone that does more wrong than it does right. I wish I had more to say here.OVERALL - 4.5 / 10PROS+ art is actually pretty goodCONS- extremely clunky movement / combat- ability point buy / upgrade system is extremely boring and lackluster- story and dialogue are cringe-worthy- lots of loading- $4 DLC single talent treesDETAILSWhile I really wanted to like this game, overall it just falls flat in all regards. From the beginning, Van Helsing has been fraught with bugs and a lack of anything going right. To start, multiplayer was completely inaccessible for the first 6-7 months after release, and many quests were bugged such that they could not be completed. Releasing an extremely buggy game: strike #1.Supposedly a lot of bugs have been fixed in the past 6 months, but this game was purchased specifically to play multiplayer at release and months went by with other (seemingly less important) bugs being fixed, and multiplayer is still not one of them. I have seen multiple instances of it being marked "fixed" in patch notes, only to find it is still as buggy as ever. Even without multiplayer, there are still a LOT of bugs that are easily found that stick out like sore thumbs. On top of this fact, DLC was apparently being worked on for the game starting after it was released, using vital manpower that should have been used to fix bugs to instead leave people that bought the game out in the cold. Focusing on future profits instead of fixing buggy products for current customers: strike #2.Turns out that all of the DLC (at this writing) just adds single talent trees to Van Helsing or the companion, Katarina, for a "measly" price of $4. Not only that, but items in the game drop that require the DLC, WITHOUT HAVING PURCHASED THE DLC. Thinking your customers are chumps with bags of money lying around: strike #3.Ranting aside, I can get past my personal issues with the motives of developers if the game is good, but I have to rack my brain for a while to just think of something nice to say. For a Diablo clone, it has about 1/10th of the content and customization of other games: there are no classes to choose from, the default talent trees (all 2 of them, one is a melee tree, the other is a ranged tree) are not viable to split putting points into unless you're playing on Easy difficulty, and each talent tree only has 8 abilities, of which you'll actually only use 3 or 4. There is no real diversity in any of the trees, either, especially since most of the abilities and upgrades are just terrible. The overall impression is that someone put way too much time and effort into making sure no single ability was powerful, even with upgrades, causing the entire combat experience to be extremely diluded. Given that Diablo clones are all about fun combat mechanics and getting loot, that should be enough to stay far away from this game. If that's your thing, though, feel free to keep reading.The gameplay of fighting enemies is in itself a chore: any ability that has any real power to it has a long cooldown, meaning that you'll spend most of your time using a basic attack that has no real flair to it. Combine that with the fact that Van Helsing's movements cause him to spend way too much time standing still when actually fighting and you have a game reminiscent of the time when ATARI made consoles and not just games. What's worse is that the clunkiness could potentially be overlooked if the abilities the player used actually looked good when fighting, but for the most part combat VFX are almost non-existent. Player abilities don’t really stand out from the rest of the world, and are so short lived that the player might wonder if they cast an ability at all. There are very few noticeable VFX from enemies, as well, and if they didn't actually have physical attack animations then I wouldn't even be sure they were attacking. A lot of times the player just seems to take damage when enemies are around, but because you fight almost everything in the game you just know to expect it.Although gameplay isn't everything, Van Helsing doesn't have much more to stand on. The dialogue between Van Helsing and his companion Katarina are terribly hokey and feels forced at all points. The art in the game is actually pretty good, but for the most part it’s all just static environments and doesn’t really engage the player at all, making it loses a lot of the potential it had at really being a “wow” moment. Because of this, some of the environments are actually very distracting and can be annoying to try and find things in, especially if there are quest-related objectives. Sound is never really my thing in games, and Van Helsing does nothing to change that. It is mostly just… there, although the constant dialogue / noises from friends and foes alike detract from whatever potential it had.I think that covers everything, hopefully it gives people a good look at what this game is actually all about. I, for one, will hopefully not be making the same mistake twice with this company, the lackluster game and their focus on money over content has left an extremely bad taste in my mouth.

												A standard top down RPG with some things different here and there.From what I've played of it, the normal difficulty is more like "very hard" and the easy is more like "here, take this fancy loot and one shot these bad guys".And thats just within the first hour of gameplay (between the two respective difficulty levels).  I don't mind a challenge.  On most games I go out of my way to pick the harder difficulty so that I don't fly through them.  But with this game, I've no choice.  The standard difficulty is so damn hard that I find it unplayable (and yes, unplayable within the first 30 mins!).People have had a lot of good to say about this game, so I won't judge just yet.  But the difficulty settings so far have me yearning for something in between a normal setting that rips you appart for not playing like a pro, and an easy difficulty that treats you as a fool.So far from what I've gathered, I'd rather spend my time playing Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												PROS:*Looks nice enough*Choice of swordsman, gunslinger, or mage for the original character; choice of mage or engineer with DLC*Unique helper who can be a melee or ranged fighter, buy and sell items for the player while he's in the field, and be customized to behave as the player wishes*Adequate number of quests*Respawning monsters can be turned on or off*Scenarios and Neverending Story provide some replayability after completing the game*Co-op with a fair loot system*Skill and stat reset and unlockable perks*Little to no need to grind*Changes in weapons and armor actually affect character appearance, though the character's size makes these changes minorCONS:*Repetitive gameplay*Visually unimpressive skills*Glitches*Slow response to glitches (newer games seem to take priority)*Uninspired story*Tedious tower defense section*Little incentive to play the additional modes*Considerable lag on even the lowest settings in some areas during co-op if one's computer doesn't meet the recommended specifications*20 GB download with little to show for it???:*Fury systemGAME LENGTH:Those who just want to complete the game on normal difficulty at a normal pace should expect to take 12-15 hours.  Achievement hunters will take varying amounts of time depending on what difficulty they choose at the start and whether or not they select hardcore mode, but should be aware that several achievements involve a great deal of grinding.  I took around 30 hours to get all of the achievements besides those related to hardcore mode and difficulty and those involving the greatest amount of grinding.SCORE:5 out of 10I happened to start playing this after an update that broke a few aspects of the game.  It took too long for the developers to address these issues and, even when they did, some remained.  For example, the Thaumaturge's blizzard skill is supposed to do a certain amount of damage in a small visible area on the screen, but instead causes massive (fatal) damage to all enemies within 2 screens of the player.  This can easily be abused to make every area and boss a joke.  I also found myself unable to complete a main quest because of a bug that prevents a quest item spawn, yet the only fix available is to actually type a command into the game.  The game has been out since May 2013 and the developers have gone on to make Van Helsing II, Van Helsing III, and a spin-off of the tower defense element of the game.  At this point, there is no excuse for persistent bugs and lazy fixes.Still, if these bugs were my only problem with the game, I would recommend it.  The trouble is that it's not particularly fun.  Gameplay consists of running from one mob of enemies to the next, using the same two or three skills again and again.  The game does feature a unique mechanic called Fury, which is gained by attacking enemies and spent to give skills unique buffs if the player has spent skill points on those buffs.  For example:  if the player uses skill points to unlock the flamethrower skill and additional skill points to unlock one of its 3-5 buffs, flamethrower might do 50% more damage or cause persistent fire damage to enemies if the buff is invoked.  However, the buff is also spent upon activation, meaning fury must be used to ready it again for any subsequent attack.  I found the system rather awkward to use because of all of the key presses involved, but others might enjoy it, so I list it neither as a pro nor a con.  In any case, it didn't change the nature or feel of the gameplay for me.The three unique bosses (one for the end of each act) offer something different, but only because the player has to first run around activating towers, completing a tower defense section, or destroying spawners first to have a good chance of killing them.  The developers apparently thought that the tower defense section of the second act was good enough to turn into a stand-alone game (Death Trap), but to me it seemed to drag on for too long.  It is like Orcs Must Die! (one of my favorite games) in the sense that the player places traps on tiles and is free to assist his traps in killing enemies, who can also target him.  However, the player must gather materials to place traps and also has a limit on how many can be placed.  The trap variety is decent, at least for what amounts to a mini-game, but in the interest of achievement hunting, I followed others' advice and used just one kind of trap:  the werewolf cage.  Perhaps the experience would have been more enjoyable if I had been more adventurous, but I doubt it.  The length of this section and the constant micromanagement with the player character, which I enjoyed in Orcs Must Die! but disliked here, just sapped any fun out of it.  And then I had to do it again for another quest.The story is arguably the biggest disappointment, as it merely amounts to a hunt for a one-dimensional villain who is out to hurt people.  There is no depth, minimal world-building, and no incentive to play apart from an interest in getting better weapons and putting points into skills, neither of which conveyed much of a sense of progression.  The player only gets enough points to max out a handful of skills, most of which both look and feel unimpressive, and the weapons all handle about the same way, with minimal boosts to damage as the player progresses.The cooperative aspect of the game was the biggest draw for me since I have a wife who occasionally likes to play.  Our first problem was getting the game to work:  even though her computer surpasses the minimum requirements and mine surpasses the recommended, we both got stuck on an endless initial loading screen.  Eventually I got it working, but it wasn't long before the next problem.  When we reached the second large map (Gallowsbog), the game lagged too much even on the lowest settings for her to be able to do anything at all.  I was forced to play the rest of the game on my own, without company to distract me from the game's other failures.After finishing the game, I had little interest in buying the next in the series.  After reading some of the reviews and glitch reports for both sequels, I lost what little interest I had left.For the tedious gameplay, poor optimization, unimpressive skills, and bugs that remain unfixed to this day, I give this game a 5 out of 10.

												If you are someone who plays games on a MAC, do not even bother buying this game. It should not be advertised as a MAC compatible game! 												Good for hours of playtime, but not much else.  The storyline is forgettable, the voice-acting is okay, and the visuals are pretty decent for this style of game.
