number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Surprisingly motivating, considering it's just a hack&shoot. Maybe it's the actual existence of a somewhat interesting story, maybe the tons of achievements.The character customization is interesting, too, though.You can choose whether to have respawning mobs or not for single player story.There are weapons that grow more powerful with use and stuff is sharable between your chars.There is some interesting variety in gameplay to shake up the relatively dull hack&shoot a bit.I play it on easy and it's still enjoyable.I got the game in a bundle though, not because I deliberately wanted to have it. Since Valve doesn't allow neutral reviews and I'm focusing on a certain downside that might be of interest to some people, I'll give this a negative one. (Really can't decide.)The amount of loot that drops in this game borders on trolling. There's too damn much loot, and the stats compare is a pain, not only because you have to do it for two characters, but because it's confusing and unreliable. A lot of the gametime tends to be about sorting out items.I think I'm only managing to keep playing it because of the achievements.(The game has a demo, so the rest you can derive from that.)- Terrain scrolling is far from being smooth. Considering the visual quality and my system, it's a bit sad. Fog even causes extreme framerate drops. This engine seems unoptimized.- Fakenook, Twitter and Youtube links on the main screen, hurting immersion. This is about as annoying as Youtubers saying "like, comment, favorite and subscribe" all the time.- And now the big issue right at the beginning:Rarely does a game bombard a personal firewall as much as this. It tries to connect to api.parse.com and amazonaws.com and oftentimes every half a second to mail.neocoregames.com (even after startup - it basically bombards your firewall permanently) and if you don't allow this stuff, then the game will freeze for several minutes before you even see the main menu.This is with a set block rule, mind you. And turning off my network is not an option since it's a Steam game. Unless you are willing to not care about the motivational factor of achievements. (Not sure whether they register in offline mode though. The game does have its own achievement UI.)First time it didn't switch to the resolution I selected, and since it can't switch it in-game, I had to wait yet another couple of minutes. I thought that would fix the ugly text, but it seems the game uses a web font without hinting, so even in native resolution text in the menus still looked ugly.Oh and if I alt-tab out of the game while it pauses with futile connection attempts, it might default to 640x480, requiring me to launch it yet again.And don't say "Just let it connect.". I pay attention to what the software on my PC tries to do, since it's necessary these days.Most games with internet connectivity get the message and don't spam firewall logs like that and stop doing anything. Especially since I already have set a block rule.(Another game that has this kind of issue (even worse) is Super Meat Boy, although there the problem might have resolved itself somehow.)P.S.: The game is a real space waster. Its videos (intro, cutscene, outro) are present in ten different languages, and the difference is really just the audio track and the subtitles. Extremely clumsy way to do that. 149 MB English videos and 912 MB other-language versions. They could have used that space to provide lossless sounds instead of OGG for example.And the map files are present as separate huge versions for low, medium and high detail. Model files too. And both sometimes are of exactly the same size. (Otherwise it would probably be necessary data.)Then again, since this game has all files separately, if you need the space and only play on high detail, you can delete 6.42 GB of terrain data alone. This plus the video thing taken care of and the game has now 11.8 GB instead of 19.1 GB.

It's a mixed bag, but a passable title if you're looking for the Diablo formula.

												It's a good action RPG.Combats are dynamic, many have an epic feel to them.However, that's the entire game - good smasher with no depth or much thought put into it: run around, kill, loot, level up (rediculous max out at Level 25).  (Try Dragon Age: Origins for comparison or Divinity II, to feel what a good RPG should be).More research into and respect toward Slavic Lore, Culture, Tradition, Mythology, and Folklore would make this game seem like it was made by serious and dedicated people, and not like it was made by teenagers whipped by the publisher to get your money.By Kiddies for Kiddies.  Half-baked and anticlimatic.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures берет другим — подачей и оформлением. Охотник за нечистью очень приятно и литературно выражается, идеально сохраняя образ; его подруга каждые 15 минут выдает остроты; окружающие персонажи продуманы и прописаны настолько, чтобы каждая из отведенных им фраз звучала свежо и интересно. В этом смысле игру хочется сравнить, наверное, с Magicka — все не настолько абсурдно, но настолько же талантливо.Отличные диалоги накладываются на постоянное обновление места действия — каждые пару часов стиль игры радикально преображается. Просторные полянки сменяются многоуровневыми улочками, классические злые вороны вытесняются изощренными франкенштейнами, а сопровождается это обновлением цветовой гаммы и музыкальной темы. Саундтрек вообще хочется выделить отдельно — очень уж он приятен для малобюджетного проекта.

												Actually i wasn't expecting much from this game. I learned about it existence only four days ago. Read some preview and wasn't impressed. But i've learened to never trust someones opinion before trying something myself.Probably because i didn't expect much i really like the game now. I was surprised with the price on it. The game seemed like a solid project and they aren't usually cost as much :D I like visual style of the game. I'm pretty tired of "childish" colors in other games. Probably i'm not creating an uber build, but i like the fact that the game always keeps me focused otherwise it'll take only a few seconds to die. And one thing i like the most about the game is the story. I have no idea how it was intended to be told, but sometimes i just can't stop laughing. And that's i guess the main thing among many more that pushes me to go ahead, I can't wait for Van Helsing and Katarina to start talking with each other or someone else again. So far i gained from Van Helsing more fun that from Titan Quest, D3 and TL2 all together. I can't remember a single sentence said by anyone in those games, but i'm sure some phrases from Van Helsing will stay with me forever.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												I cannot on good conscience recommend this game for anything other than the hilariously dodgy writing and voice acting.Pros:-The dialog is silly, it's super dorky and great.-No one seems bothered by the ghost lady at your side-Not using the word "g*psy", since it's a slur (they use 'Romany' instead to pretend they're not Romani) Cons:-Only 1 character class unless you buy the DLC-Lag, lag, worse lag-Bosses are terribly unbalanced, a team of 4 people on normal could not beat the scarecrow-Shrines don't work-Waypoints don't always work when you use them-Crashed frequently for my group-Mob balance issues, half of a 4 player group should not die at level 3 when fighting mooks.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Van Helsing trys to be serious with its pretty dark and grey steampunk citys. On the other hand you find a lot of humor in the characters. This works very well and gives you a good feeling while playing the game. The length of the campaign is okay with 10-12 hours. I finished the game twice, because the other character you can choose from ( if you own the dlcs) looked pretty interesting to me. Not a WOW game, but recommendable for everyone with a budget, since the game is very cheap. Personal rating 7 / 10

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing looks like a great game. I was very excited to try this, and when it came up in the recent holiday sale, I nabbed it. Before buying, I verified that the game supports Mac and controllers. These top down games are some of my favorites, and I prefer the game controller to mouse and keyboard for them. Unfortunately, it seems that Mac is supported and controller is supported, but the two together are not supported. So I have not been able to play. I gave them almost four months to patch this issue, but, while other updates have been coming out, no fix for controllers on Macs has been seen. I won't buy another NeoCore game. I find their practices deceptive.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												BIG WARNING! I hate to write this review. The game itself looks great. The atmosphere and especially the ghost girl Katrina and her antics are soo cute. But what put me off and ask Steam for a refund within 30 minutes of gameplay is severe fps drops and comstant lag in single player mode itself.I am playing on ASUS ROG machine which runs almost any game at high/ultra settings but this 'normal' ARPG is causing pain in the butt. Obviously, the game isn't optimized at all with respect to performance. Even the graphics, its bit strange they look absoultely great when it comes to details but there is something missing feeling. It might have to do with washed out look and fuzzyness. Many times i have to wide open my eyes to read a text or see an item clearly. You won't be surprised to loose focus on your character when he is surronded by hoards of enemies. The shades are so washed out that everthing gets mixedup quite often.If you think the game suits you, buy it by all means and be prepared to ask for a refund incase your pc also has the same problems running this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Would be a great hack'n'slash Diablo-clone game with witty banter and storyline if only it weren't for the frustratingly constant CTDs that lose your progress each time they occur.  Forums show many others having the same problem, and turning off Steam Saves did help significantly reducing the CTDs from every single time you made an area transition to once every 3 or 4 times, but that's still far too many CTDs that prevent you from enjoying an otherwise fun game. There were many other bugs that are unfixed in the game as well, but most of those have workarounds to resolve them in the Community Forums. I had decided to try to finish this game before buying the sequel, but never could finish because of the frequent CTDs, which honestly will keep me from buying the sequel. Truly sad because it was rather growing on me despite all the other bugs.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												If I had to pick an "underrated game of 2013" this is it. Beautiful animations, a compelling setting, an interesting AI companion, and an adequate story already set this game apart from its competitors in the ARPG market - and that's to say nothing of character development and the combat mechanics system. A lot of criticisms of this game target the lack of build diversity, since the vanilla version only has one character "class" with two build paths, melee and ranged. However, these concerns are ameliorated by the DLC classes, a mage and a trap-setting ranged fighter, which are worth getting if you like the base game. I love the setting, which is somewhere between Mary Shelley / Bram Stoker Gothic and Stephen Hunt steampunk. Katarina, the ghost companion of the player, is well-written and feels useful in combat (but not TOO useful, so van Helsing still feels like the star.)Combat is simple enough to be accessible, but complex enough to reward careful character building. 4 primary stats - essentially Melee, Ranged, Magic, and Critical - govern around 10 secondary stats, all of which are easy to understand. The skill tree is fairly simple but has enough depth that the same class could be built effectively in a few different ways. There is a neat mechanic about managing a resource called Rage, used to enhance attacks with sub-skills called Powerups; so far these seem interesting, but not necessary to play the game if you don't want to worry about them.I got this game on sale for $7, and at that price it's a no-brainer. At the full price ($15 + $5 DLC) it's still worthwhile, but there are better titles on Steam at that price point if you're not an action-RPG fan. In comparison to Torchlight 2, it is a bit less accessible to genre newcomers, but with a more interesting setting and a darker, more visceral tone. TOTAL 8.5/10+ Art style and setting+ Animations and voice acting+ Combat system (Power-ups/rage, balance of skills, diversity of skills and gear)+ Endgame play modes (Scenario and Neverending Story allow players to continue after finishing the game)- Feels limited by production cost (Short story, only a few monster models and terrain palettes)- Some technical problems (occasional, minor bugs that do not crash the game, but get irritating)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												This is a hard game to review. On the one hand they do a lot of right things and on the other a lot of wrong things. The graphics are very nice and the sounds are good. The music is awful and I had to mute it. The music loops and its not very good.  The lore behind the game is original and the quests are fun for the most part.  The things I didnt like is the game is a lot harder then it should be. On Normal your going to be running for your life a lot of the time or least I was. I would say on normal for this game would be like hard or higher on Diablo 3. Mostly its because of the lack of regen on the armor stuff.The casual mode is ok but a little to easy. I wouldnt mind something in between. The skill tree is still in my opinion is all over the place and messy to look at. I would like something like torchlight 2 or Diablo 3 more streamlined. You have auros, tricks, skill sets for melee or shooting and then you have subset skills  whithin the skills that you can activate via rage by fighting things. If that sounds confusing well it is. A lot more then it should. The Co Op seems to work fine for the person hosting more so then the joiner. I had a gambler inside my base the person who joined couldnt talk to him. A fun game but can be frusterating in a lot of small ways.  After playing this for a while I would give it a 7/10 some good ideas hampered by small issues. Just beat the game in Co-Op its a little buggy and there was some lag,  even on a lan? Go Figure.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Would be a great hack'n'slash Diablo-clone game with witty banter and storyline if only it weren't for the frustratingly constant CTDs that lose your progress each time they occur.  Forums show many others having the same problem, and turning off Steam Saves did help significantly reducing the CTDs from every single time you made an area transition to once every 3 or 4 times, but that's still far too many CTDs that prevent you from enjoying an otherwise fun game. There were many other bugs that are unfixed in the game as well, but most of those have workarounds to resolve them in the Community Forums. I had decided to try to finish this game before buying the sequel, but never could finish because of the frequent CTDs, which honestly will keep me from buying the sequel. Truly sad because it was rather growing on me despite all the other bugs.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												While it's fun to hear the dialogue between the ghost lady and your character on certain events, the slaying monster game play is quite boring. Most of the skill tree are auras or passives. There are very few interesting skills, which you can already tell by simply looking at the icon of the skill, the icons are copied and changed a bit for the next ones in the tree. The terrain is buggy on certain place, you're running but not moving. The environment looks nice and fresh however.Exploring the map once was interesting but it isn't worth revisiting after. The two game modes after completing the game are mostly grinding.The combat is definitely the weakest part of this game.If it's on sales and you like RPG get it, play once then forget about it. Otherwise, games like TL2, PoE and D3 are far more superior.

												A quality aRPG that is sure to have gone under the radar of many. A unique story with a follower that levels alongside you, and many of the modern streamlining conveniences similar to Torchlight 2 that have their own added intricacies. Having only one class with others behind DLC is a bit bothersome, but the standard class is versatile on its own and the campaign is a good length. Postgame goes beyond the standard new game+ and adds especially hard challenge missions to the mix.  Overall, a must for the aRPG fan.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is an average Action-RPG that is clearly outshone by other games in the genre. There are fair sized skill and talent trees that are hindered by limited hotkeys and level requirements. These trees allow for a multitude of ways to spend skill points and while it would imply replayability to neutralise the fact that there are only three classes, builds are far too restricted by the lack of available skill points and level restrictions. The three available classes are not very flexible in playstyle apart from the Hunter, but even that only has the choice to switch between melee and ranged. The combat has a focus on area-of-effect skills as the game can easily swarm you with monsters at ambiguous and undefined spawn points that can even be on top of you without warning. Loot drops occur too often and has uninteresting basic stat upgrades which taints the experience of obtaining new and better equipment. The plot is uninteresting and written poorly, the voice acting is subpar as they do not portray their characters' intent appropriately. The environments, despite varied, are cliche and does not compensate for the lack of world building that the plot, characters and ambience do not provide. Cooperative play is available but seems tacked on and is the same experience as the singleplayer, but with added players and monster difficulty.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												A LOT better than I originally thought it would be. When it was first released I was not at all interested, it looked cheap, generic, dull and just another fan fiction game with no substance. Damn, was I wrong. The base version only comes with one playable class(?) but with the DLC you can then choose from two more, the Thaumaturge which is basically your mage and the Arcane Mechanic wich is an engineer with cool gadgets. Very different from most birds eye view RPG's I've played, different gearing and gemming mechanics and styles but it does not lack what only some can offer: a fun, changing, new, challenging, mass killing, awesome adventure. The skill system works the same as most other games like this would, as you level up (killing monsteres, completeing quests, etc.) you gain skill poins, later on though you gain more per level but in turn your higher level abilities require more and one skill point (1, 2 and some 3). You have your main ability skills, (mostly activated and damaging abilities, some passive) Your Tricks ability page (special abilities that change or enhance game play [Thaumaturge can slow time for every thing around him, Arcane Mechanic can summon turrets, and other fun abilities]). And last are your Aura skills, you can have 2 auras on at a time that increase mana regen, critical damage boost, elemental damage increase, etc. The game play, design, UI lay out and the game mechanics are very user friendly. One thing that most games lack is undoing skill point allocation. In this game you can remove points from skills one point at a time (for a fee, of course) so you don't totally throw you build out the window, you can instead make samll tweaks to it, which I love. You can do the same for you Ability points: Body(STR equiv) Dexterity(AGI euiv) Willpower (INT equiv) and Luck (magic item find, crit chance, dodge change modifier). Your follower, Katarina, is a sassy spectre that helps out in battle but also adds a sense of humor to a seemingly bleak dark world. She has her own seperate Skillys and Abilities and you can change how she attacks and behave (Melee, Ranged, Passive while adding boosts to you). You can have her pick up items, and gold if you want, send her to town to do your shopping and she will back talk you the entire time. Different and weird at first, but she is a valuable asset to your goal of evil eradication. There's a lot to say about this game, but you will just have to play it for your self to experience the fun and actually quite enjoyable graphics. There are some zones that feel laggy and I did have to tweak my video settings for it to be a little less glitchy at times (Running with two GTX 670 vid cards, i7 3.4Ghz, 16Gb RAM, 1 TB HD with a 240Gb SSD) my computer is more than capable of running any game at max graphics setting but I still experienced lag at times. Like any game, there are glitches and bugs that can some times even progression imparing, check the forums, the game has a built in repair function if a quest stops working or something similar, nothing major but it can be frustrating at times.My over all verdict 8/10. Worth buying? Yes. Better with friends? Yes. I'ts a fun game and I have thoroughly enjoyed playing it.

There are different classes for different playstyles, and items that, frustratingly, can only be used by a particular class. The sense of humor built into this game is priceless.Can money buy happiness? Now it can.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												I have to say I really enjoyed my first play  through of this little gem of an ARPG. Honestly my only gripe was the somewhat forced linear progression of some areas and a lack of mob respawning mechanics or procedurally generated side quests dungeons to create a deeper more replayable experience for even a single character. This combined with a fairly short playthrough time left me feeling honestly abit annoyed considering Torchlight 2 when onsale as it so frequently goes and its huge workshop mod community makes it such a modern titant among ARPGs that should be considered by others developing in the genre.The fact you have to pay for various classes as DLC vs again TR2s active modder community and free classes to explore need to be kept in mind by would be rivals. Still I honestly didnt mind grabbing the DLC for this game as it did show enough potential I wanted to try and show all the support I could.The vibes this game gives off are honestly the best of the ARPGs Ive seen for a while. The voice acting, banter from your ghostly lady companion, the story over all has a fun factor I have to admit captured my steam punkish goth nature very solidly.To me the real hidden treasure is the eventual base you get to set up and the handful of defense events you get to enjoy. IMO these needed to be more frequent or something, the system though alot of fun to watch the creatures die in the traps  and think it would of been great to see there be a way to have endless invasion options at the end to add to extending the life of a given play through.Over all if you enjoy the various related genres, the ARPG genre, and enjoy a shorter playthrough game to see the end I totally encourage this game for a easy dif with hardcore on one and done play approach for each class currently out.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This is a very fun ARPG. The play mechanics are excellent, the maps are huge, the quests are fun, and, for a lower budget game, the voice acting is quite nice. There are two DLCs thus far and for those who have the game, the dev has offered a unique item and an aura as a thank you. Diablo, Torchlight, Grim Dawn, and other ARPG players will feel right at home with this game. There is a LOT of loot, a nice skill tree for your main character plus your ghost companion - she is a blast BTW with her snide and condescending remarks to Van Helsing. But, unlike the annoying companion in Legend: Hand of God, THIS companion is also a potentially gruesome, merciless killing machine. The DLC offers more replayability, but, even without it, you can play through the game again and specialize in different kinds of attacks - the same goes for your companion.This game LOVES to swarm you and enemies will attack in all directions - it's absolutely glorious and at times, loot drops can be almost as crazy as Torchlight II.I hope that Neocore will consider making a sequel. The game would easily compete with the best triple A ARPGs out there. A random map function would really round the game out. Props to the devs who have been VERY responsive and have kept this jewel up to date. I am an ARPG fanatic and The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is one of the most fun I am still playing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												I picked this up as part of a Humble Bundle and had a couple of false starts at getting into it, primarily due to my lack of familiarity with the character set-up possibilities. I am very glad I had another crack as this is good fun. The mechanics are fairly standard but have plenty of customisation options (although there is the occasional problem with not being able to move when surrounded - best avoided by not allowing yourself to get surrounded!) but it's the very nicely rendered and varied environments and tongue-in-cheek humour that make the game. It's clearly been developed by people that love the genre (both of the game and its source material) and there is a lot of detail applied to enhance the gamer's experience. There are loads of easter eggs, jokes and achievements as well (some very much more obscure than others). Definitely worth a go if you enjoy horror B-movies and/or hacking/blowing up hordes of baddies.

number of helpful: 11 of 24 people (46%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												What's with all them people recommending abysmal, amateur games lately? Stop feeding me this pig grub and making me spend money on trash titles that only waste my time.Van Helsing is basically a shovelware title made only to generate income for the least possible costs possible. It's your standard, soulless, mediocre-but-annoyingly-bad-at-the-end hack'n'slash. Everything in this game screams with lack of creativity, the lack of any ultimate point of this title being even made besides "people will buy anything at steam sales" logic.Yeah, let's take an interesting theme and turn it into another uninspired shovelware. I fiddled around a little with characters, progressed a little into the story but the fundamentals of the gameplay, controls and the balance (that ranged class was a total afterthought, it's so underpowered and limited compared to the hunter) turned out to be terribly implemented and got me ultimately bored on hard difficulty. There's literally nothing of interest in this game, everything was done before and better. But the worst part is that killing enemies is fiddly (targeting is a chore, especially with the ranged character) and absolutely unrewarding, which means it's unsatysfying. Even putting down boss enemies turns into running in circles taking that HP bloat down for some crappy loot worse than anything you get from a vendor. Oh, yeah, how about tying difficulty level with number of enemies? That can't go wrong, can it? Yeah, it can and it did, because the only thing it changes is forcing the player into doing more circles kiting enemies until they all go down. How about♥♥♥♥♥♥voice actors on the top of that? Apparently some people liked them generic characters with terrible va - and terrible dialogue lines in this game are being described as "humorous". What? Straightforward terrible references and unfunny lines are "humorous" now? Seriously?Hard to see a good h'n's lately. Just get Torchlight 2 which is better in everything from Van Helsing. Even if it has arguably worse esthetics.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												If you've played Torchlight 2, you'll know what to expect.  The common root is Diablo, but The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing *is* Torchlight 2, to the extent that it feels like a rather underdone mod rather than a game in its own right.That's fine, of course - inbreeding and cheeky rip-offs have always been rampant in the games industry.  It doesn't matter if a game resembles another, what matters is what it brings to the table.  Van Helsing comes up very short, sadly, and the best that can be said about it is that it'll remind you of better games from time to time.Functionally it has everything you'd want from a game of this type, although it is a little buggy and nowhere near as configurable as it should be, but it feels like the work of people who got their game engine roughly working without any passion for the game they'd make with it.   It kind of pulls the right moves, but nothing really clicks.  Enemies are never exciting challenges, they're just pests who are either overpowered or underpowered, and combat is a constant annoyance.  A *constant* annoyance, as it never lets up - outside of safe town areas, fresh waves of enemies will always flood at you, which means that attempting to navigate the unnecessarily fussy character sheets, or even your inventory, will often result in death.You will die often, but it'll rarely be the result of something you have or haven't done.  Sometimes it will be down to the nice but confusing art style that makes your character impossible to find on the screen, but generally it's down to this game having absolutely nothing to do at any turn other than a weak sigh and 'eh, throw more enemies in there?'It's porridge floating in bathwater.  It's a game designed by people who don't understand games.  It's like eating a roll of wallpaper.  It is - and I don't say this lightly - perhaps the most tedious game I've ever played.  I go back to the Spectrum era, so I've seen some stinkers.  There's nothing here for anyone other than boredom.

Posted: July 28, 2016
												Well it can be fun to play and the writing isn't terrible the game can be somewhat unstable, may just be certain setups that run into instability but it can get rather annoying, as it has a demo available I heavily advise running the demo for at least a few hours before considering buying.The defaulting to gamepad if one is plugged in may annoy some as might the kb/m UI which is all over the place, the gamepad UI is slightly off no matter what on my 16:10 setup so I thought a bar in a cetain mission was full when it had a bit left.I personally have had several instances where it stopped registering my gamepad as plugged in and would't accept any input requring alt-f4-ing (luckily it saves frequently), when reforging items I've ran into a lot of crashes.Outside all the bugs/crashes and other issues the gameplay is decent for a diablo-like or whatever that subgenre is called, the voice acting isn't terrible and the story works.You spend most of the game running around murdering hordes of enemies in search of ever slightly better gear with that minor stat increase you need to kill them that bit faster.If you've played diablo or any of the games like it you know what to expect from the gameplay more or less and it's not anywhere near the worst of its type.So yeah, it's a fine game if you're lucky enough that it isn't completely unstable for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2013
												I grew up on a diet of late night monster movies and bad scifi flicks and if there's one thing I retained from those days, it's the knowledge that Van Helsing is the most bad♥♥♥♥♥monster hunter there is.  Well...some of the Van Helsing's are.  You see, in history, there's like 912 different Van Helsing's out there.   I think they're all related too, but I'm not 100% on that.  Some are kick♥♥♥♥♥ some are not.  The Van Helsing in this game though is clsoer to the kick♥♥♥♥♥end of the scale. Even though I'm 40, I stil dream of being a monster slayer when I grow up.  It's probably never going to happen though, so having a monster slayer simulator is pretty nice.  This Van Helsing game pits you against large waves of monsters and let's you feel like Peter Cushing in a Hammer flick as you go to town with your dual swords, blood flying left and right and monsters falling like chumps.  (Two swords are always cooler than one sword, or a rifle you amateur)  As far as Action RPG's go, Van Helsing's a weird hybrd sandwiched between the buns of Diablo II and Torchlight II.  You get some min-maxing of stats on items, but not enough to feel like a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥lord, plus a limited amount of skills that make you actually think before you plunk your points down so that you don't wind up with a Van Helsing with a limp sword arm.  Plus, the environments are pretty nice and gothic with a creepy atomsphere, again like a Hammer flick so it plays well to horror nerds, such as myself. The game can be pretty tough, you're going drink potions like an addict and you're going to swear at your monitor a lot, but making up swear words is a fun part of being a gamer.   it still feels rewarding to be able to come up with a combination of wepons strenth and skill points to be able to kick the snot out of that werewolf that's been having it's way with your hind parts.   There's two downfall's to Van Helsing, one being that it's a one and done playthrough, meaning you're not going to play through it obsessively seven times to become the prettiest princess with the shiniest breast plate, but it's pretty fun for that one play through.   The other is that one of the things I enjoy in ARPG's the playing dress up with your toon to be the prettiest princess, finding the coolest looking.  Van Helsing's getup isn't going to change a whole lot throughout the game, but he still looks pretty cool to start.  He looks cooler than Hugh Jackman did as Van Helsing at the very lest.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												My Bite Sized Review - The Incredible Adventures of Van HelsingThe Good:+New game in the world of Van Helsing+Controller Enabled+Start the game with a companion that talks and can be used in combat+A good amount of different playstyles+Story through campanion banter is done wellThe Bad:-Graphics are very outdated-Combat is very standard (melee, magic, or guns)-Unlike Diablo 3 once you spend points into a build, you are stuck with it unless you pay gold to respec-Enviroments are not that different (All kind of run together)-Zombie AI (aka just run at character)-Elite Mobs kill you quick, but themselves are just bullet sponges with average combat tactics-In the late game, you are forced to just keep popping healing potions and mana to stay alive-Quests are forgetable and not that interestingThe Verdict:I will say I DO recommend this game if it is heavily discounted. Other than that though, this game is a very average diablo style role playing game. The combat and graphics show their age and mid to late game there is a boost in difficulty that I feel is very un-necessary. Like in Diablo 3 I understand that on Hell Difficulty it would be really hard, but here in this game mid way through enemies just start taking chunks out of you even though you have decent equipment. All in all a very average game that might not get recommended before some other games in the genre (For Example Titan Quest or Torchlight).

number of helpful: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Before I get started with this review, I'll go ahead and point out that I'm not an expert. No really, loot-based action-rpgs aren't really my forte. Sure I've spent hundreds if not thousands of hours on titles like Diablo 2 and its ilk, but I couldn't tell you a dang thing about any of them. Go ahead and ask me about Diablo 2, all I recall is Tristram run after Blood run after Baal run after run after run after...bleah. I fried my brain on the genre years ago so I have just a little understanding for "strategy", "proper-builds", and the inner-workings and mechanics of what makes this genre function. I still play them though because they're addictive as hell. Now then, what can I say about Van Helsing? Well, for starters the characters are a bit more amusing than most. This is one of the benefits of having a game where the main-characters stay the same no matter the class. Despite his appearance, Helsing is a good-humored dude, and isn't always deadly serious about his job. His ghostly partner Katarina always has a cutting remark ready for the vampire hunter. As a duo they're far more memorable than most loot-clicker casts. I went with ranged-build, mostly relying on the spread-shot for crowd-control. Kat was built to violently explode upon "death" for great damage. It worked out well enough I suppose. I played on hard difficulty and didn't run into many problems (didn't beat the game, more on that later).Van Helsing plays out much the same as any other loot-clicker. You have your equipment, your rares, your skills, and your build. Either through happenstance or a guide you find your build, you choose the right skills for it, allocate the appropriate stats, then just kill stuff for appropriate weapon upgrades. For some gamers, that's compelling enough on its own, but it's preferable to hunt for something more. Where Van Helsing falters is mostly in the map-design. Each area is largely uninteresting. Some areas (like the ink realm) are visually inventive, but that's about it. The maps in this game are largely just a lot of space filled with packs of enemies. Nothing really changes as you progress. In the forest you'll run into packs of wolves, somewhere else there will be packs of soldiers, or packs of demons, and so on. When monsters are grouped together like that the game becomes stagnant. After you've found your build you're not likely to use more than the same or 2 or 3 skills at all times. Variety isn't just fighting different monsters, it's fighting monsters that approach in different ways. Some should ambush, others call for help, hell maybe they're just wandering around. In this game, they just wait around in organized groups for a vampire hunter to come fight them. One particular area is also aggravating because it is split into two sections, which leads to several minutes (slight exaggeration) of wandering back to square one if you go the wrong way. I will give credit to one area in that portions of it are separated by chasms, so enemies can take pot-shots at you as you try to cross. Sure it's headache-inducing, but at least it's inducing a feeling of something more and not just "oh look. All these monsters are standing around for the thousandeth time" mediocrity....But I didn't quit the game yet.A real frustrating aspect of this game involves the hit mechanics. More precisely, when enemies attack, what constitutes a hit? When I see an enemy wind-up to attack -- pull their fist back, hold an axe over their head, etc. -- I should be able to move out of the way to dodge it. Loot-Clickers..no...Action-RPGs in general have dozens of stats, even a dodge rating. All the same, there should be an incentive for players to avoid attacks through direct-input, not just their number > the enemy's number. Van Helsing flicks a toothpick at that idea, and it is a consistent source of annoyance for me. Even when I'm clear out of the way of an attack I'll still take damage. But that's not why I quit the game.After a certain point Van Helsing is given control of a resistance base, and he can outfit it as he sees fit. This is basically the tower defense portion of the game and THANKFULLY it's largely optional. I put the emphasis on THANKFULLY because I hated it that much. I'm going to change subjects ever so slightly and talk about a PS2 game called Shining Force Exa. In this game there is a fortress that is regularly attacked. While one character is questing, the other holds down the fort (so to speak). When you strip enough elements away from tower-defense you're left with nothing but "protect this thing". However if the core of the game is entertaining enough, that doesn't really matter. I actually enjoyed these battles in Exa because they focused on the core. A lot of monsters were thrown at the player and that was the extent of it. Van Helsing has this whole set-up where you can buy traps and place them all over this corridor-abundant dungeon. The waves of enemies are too frequent, come from too many angles, and due to the way the dungeon is constructed you'll never reach them in time. You have to approach these battles almost entirely with a tower-defense mindset. This isn't what I signed up for when I started playing Van Helsing. To be fair, tower-defense was a hardly a thing when Exa came out, but really who wants to play that crap when they pick up an action-RPG?...But I didn't quit the game at that point. After all the tower-defense stuff is largely optional.No I didn't actually quit Van Helsing until I was maybe one or two dungeons away from the final boss. When Katarina had reached her level-cap, and Helsing was maybe one or two levels away from his, I quit. Yes, of all the things to quit a game over it's due to hitting a level-cap. Or maybe the real reason is because it dawned on me that this is only part one of Van Helsing's incredible adventures. I'm sure if I picked up the second game I'd get to continue leveling, to continue fighting in seemingly endless repetitive encounters, using the same skills I mastered hours ago, dealing with the crappy mechanics, and there'd probably be even more tower-defense garbage. I didn't think myself capable of stomaching another 15-20 hours of a sequel to this game, so I quit.I'll give credit where it's due, Van Helsing managed just enough in getting the basics down to keep me playing. I'm an exceptional case though, I play a lot of loot-clickers regardless of quality, so maybe my judgment isn't always sound. If I see yellows, purples, and golds dropping at a decent enough rate there's no telling what games I could be tricked into playing. It's only when the end of the road is in sight do I realize that maybe this game isn't for me and move on. This is where Van Helsing lies. It's not particularly bad, but it gave me reason enough to quit as soon as I shook out of its icy grip.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
PlotFelt that the plot wasn't too pronounced during the entire gameplay experience, was quite confused at the end. It felt more like no-brainer progression. Adding onto that, the ending was quite abrupt and unexpected as I expected more but it's continued on on part II in which I haven't tried yet (and I don't really plan to due to its negative reviews)GameplayMovementGameplay was very smooth in general, felt that movement is rather odd if you were to move with a mouse as you can't really move and shoot at the same time, which makes attacking + defending quite choppy.CombatHowever, to make up for that, I appreciate the over the top swarms of monsters that can be slain through 1 single AOE attack which makes the experience quite satisfying.CompanionQuite liked the companion option as it allows you to stay behind a tank if you're planning on a ranged character (I played range). Adding onto that, companions allows you to sell items (almost) anywhere in the battlefield with the drawback that you give up her presence for 60 secondsInventoryFelt that the inventory management was pretty dang good considering it automatically optimizes inventory space as you collect more items, it even has a manual sort button there just in case. Your companion also helps in clearing up your inventory space by having a separate inventory space of her own (in which you can send her to sell items too)SkillsFelt that skills were a bit lackluster as compared to games nowadays, felt that they could expand more on the skill tree but I think it is just barely enough for completing the gameEnchantments/UpgradesSimilarly, quite lackluster, the enchantments and upgrades were... not too appealling, it's mostly basic upgrades like HP+, HP Drain, MP Drain, Elemental Damage etc. It doesn't really explore into more experimental elements that a hack & slash game could go with, but as I've said, the basic enchantments/upgrades should suffice for a basic game like this.BalanceContext: I played on Casual which is the defaultThe game scales to ridiculous difficulty amounts at further levels (found that after level 20 it becomes annoyingly hard to progress). Though there's a mode for you to farm equipments on with respawning monsters, you can only access it at levels higher than 27 (I believe). Kind of a bit too far away from the point where you'd normally get really frustrated.One example would be a monster that shoots a bomb, as a ranger, you'd expect yourself to have very little health if you weren't expecting these monsters; it deals immense damage, close to 80% of my health as a ranger and it basically OHKO's you at higher levels if you don't have (very) good armor and health.Well if you're a ranger can't you just shoot him down at long range?No, the problem is that, the area that the game lets you hit the monster is exactly the range of the monster, so you'd have to shoot and run. With the sloppy movement I find it really hard and annoying to kill these monsters, and I don't really even want to go into dealing 2 of these at the same time.Camera AngleOne of my biggest issues would be the camera angle.First of, the game doesn't allow you to rotate the camera at all, so you're kinda stuck with this 45 degree camera view all the time. The biggest problem is that there will be enemies coming at you from the bottom of the camera (in which is a blind spot), you wouldn't know what's hitting you until you go really close to them or you take a detour. As a ranger, it was a horrific experience most of the time.AudioVoice ActingVoices were on point, think it is better than that of most games even. The contents of the dialogue were well balanced in comedic value and seriousness, not too much of any in which I feel is a good composition.Sound EffectsComparing to games nowadays, sound effects here are subpar, if you're very picky in audio, you might find these a bit of a nuisance, but I managed to get over them.MusicMusic was decent, felt that there were some mastering errors here and there (some tracks felt quite muffled for some reason) but it is okay in potraying the mood at their respective positionsConclusion/TL;DRThough The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing has its better days in the past, it doesn't have the better perks of other similar games that are out right now.Think Torchlight II or Path of Exile would be a significantly better choice than this right now, Path of Exile is even freeAs of now, wouldn't really recommend it

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Becomes too boring after one Playtrough, also especially if you want get all Achievements its boring and there are not enough Enemy to kill, thats why i spend 177 Hours with this Crap to finally reach the 500'000 Kills.Because i was really bored already, i used a Wrench on the Controller to hold the Button down, positioned the Character to kill endless respawning Monsters in Front, for almost 24 Hours to reach the 500'000 Kills also because the Game became slower and slower because the Bodys was not removed, i was forced to use an Attack that desintegrate them, Boring, Boring, Boring!So i can only recommend it partially for one Playtrough, but there is no Replayvalue other than boring Grinds for the boring Achievements probably made only to artificially lengthen the Completion - BORING!Did i already mention this Game is Boring?Also the most Boring Thing is limited Storage, its only 4x your Inventory Space(with Perk), so you will spend alot of Time with boring sorting out good stuff to replace it with a little better stuff.I can't recommend it because i can't stand limited Storage in Games where Loot is a Core-Component.I hardly managed to put all my Epics i got into the Storage and there was no Duplicates, so Storage is defintely too small. Period.And Games with limited Storage like this, will get an automatically "Not Recommended" by me, from now one. Period.Also there is another Thing that made it even more boring, there was a Sort of Badass-Points Thing like in Borderlands, where you was able to spend Points in and those Buffs would then be for all Characters - a Thing that would mean some Replayvalue after all, but, but ... but they removed it in an older Update, so it doesn't worked anymore by the Time i got the Game, and so there is also no Replayvalue anymore. Period.Also there are Bugs, it says full Controller Support, but this isn't true!Some Skills, Auras and Stuff can only be set with Mouse and this means you have to unplug the Controller and restart the Game to set the Skills, Auras and Stuff and then plug back the Controller and restart the Game again - soooo Boring!!!It should really be called: The Incredible Boring Adventures of Van HelsingAnd because i also got both of them in a Pack, i have to finish the other too, hope it's less Boring to finish it else it's the last Game from Neocore i bought for sure.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing or Great Expectations (game review) - Hello, fellow hunters!!! As for me I was looking forward to the date of Van Helsing release with great expectations and even pre-ordered it on Steam. Frankly speaking I motivated by two things: I had already walked through Torchlight 2 several times (choosing a new character class every time) and I generally liked the videos the developers placed at Steam, Youtube and Facebook. So I bought it about two weeks before the release date. And finally I have downloaded the game and played it. I can say I have some mixed feelings about The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing.  As for the plot it is rather simple and can't boast of some depths. I mean if you happened fortunately (or unfortunately – it’s up to you to decide) to have a name of Van Helsing and your prominent father was a prominent vampire hunter – what are you expected to do and earn your living and reputation? Naturally, to kill vampires and other (numerous) various monsters. So our character goes to some imaginary country of Borgovia where something is going definitely wrong. As you guess Van Helsing is to put the situation to rights. By the way he is helped by Katarina – a ghost who has her own abilities and skills. But generally it is not the storyline that disappointed me. I never expected it to be exciting. What I wished was exciting gameplay.Read more at http://www.viewforum.net/gaming-dept-171/incredible-adventures-van-helsing-great-expectations-game-review-3359/

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												I could tell you so many things about this game.How it is charming, funny, addictive and actually has combat that is satisfying and weighty.I could tell you how this is the anti-Torchlight and anti-Diablo 3 in that it actually improves the ARPG genre by its mere existence.  That it isn't a cashgrab and it harkens back to the days when games were actually designed and had love and care put into them.How it is neither an "evolution" or "revolution" of the genre (or any other buzzword for that matter), but just a damn good game for once.But the only thing I need to tell you is that Abed from Community is the final boss.Happy hunting.  Best $20 you'll spend on Steam.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
THis game  could have easliy been a lot better. One of the silly mistakes that they did is they have 3 classes to choose from But they are all Van Helsings just in different clothes.. They Might as well have stuck with one character and given him a tree allowing he to learn everything..In my opinion this game is  like a budget Diablo 3 But no where near as good. I will compare it to Diablo 3 throughout this review to give you a gadge since you have most probably played Diablo 3. Only really one character to choose from with a different skin and different item & skill setsIn Diablo 3 there are about 5 or 6 charactors to choose from The graphics are no where near as good as Diablo 3.The game gets boring a lot quicker the Diablo 3 did. As you can see I only have 1.7 hours on record.. That is because I  really could'nt be bothered playing any further Because its not a good game.Even if I try to justify it not being at the same level as Diablo 3  By saying this game only cost $14.95 and diablo 3 is $90, there are still better free options like path of exile and much better options at simular prices like Torch light 2..  I took a chance on this game because I got it for a $1 from HumbleBundle.com in one of their weekly sales so I dont feel bad about buying this game. But I would feel a but annoyed if I had paid $14.95Therefore I can not recomend this game.   If you really want to try it even after reading this review maybe buy it if it pops up again in one of the charity bundles or goes on sale at the steam store for 80-90% off or something.But don't pay full price for this or you will be disapointed

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Now I know I may have given this game a thumbs down, but there is no “Meh” rating to give and I certainly wouldn’t give a whole hearted thumbs up.Let me start off by saying, I knew this game was going to be badish. I fully expected this game to be pure crap, but was pleasantly surprised that it was just slight crap. The voice acting, wow, its just so bad. Like they hired three people based on the number of silly voices they can make bad.I did however purchase this game Wanting to hear bad voice overs and just see how bad this game could be. So in that respect I was not disappointed.I do have to say the game functions just fine. There is nothing technically wrong with the game, the gameplay is boring and repetitive the same as the quests and missions. They crammed in some sort of tower defense game that seems a bit out of place. I purchased the expansions as well. The mage (or whatever they are calling the mage) seems ok, but if you are doing it right you will always be a glass cannon. If you spec into more durability then you wont do nearly enough damage to kill stuff and you end up taking more hits so it’s a wash.The engineer seems fun and has a flame thrower or ice thrower and lots of robot pets that run around attacking stuff.The loot however seem to be mostly geared toward the default vanilla character. Im not sure if it was just my experience or not, but it seem like most of the items dropped are geared towards the hunter class. Oh well at least my annoying ghost has a wide range of things to wear and use while she constantly talks and annoys me.Ultimately I liken playing this game to watching cheesy B minus movies, a guilty pleasure, but ultimately it will get old and you will long for a better experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												Okay, I can't really decide whether I for or against this game and I have valid reasons for that.First of all, as soon as you start the game there is already a in-game microtransaction thrown in your face (actually two of them) and this is if you want to change you character class (mage, hunter etc.) and I don't agree with that at all, you should be able to choose what class your character is without having to pay for it (DLC).The second thing about this game is the voice acting, It may or may not just be me but the voice acting in this game infuriates me, it's not that it's bad, it's just that there is clearly no effort put into the voices nor the dialogue, it is barable but that it one of the main reason why I stopped playing this game and requested a refund (I know it's a stupid reason but every player has their critism about a game and each player is different).Also, this game, oh my, it is UNBELIEVABLY hard, even on the 'normal' difficulty or I may just be complete♥♥♥♥♥♥at this game lmao..Another thing, the mechanics. Now i've played a few MMORPG games, such as, 'Path of Exile' 'Diablo 2-3' and I know what to expect when it comes to in game mechanics. The movement of your character is clunky, boring, slow and just confusing, controlling your character isn't as smooth as you'd like it to be and the skill tree, points, leveling system are absolutely rubbish. The game doesn't explain them in enough detail for you to completely understand them, basically throws you right into the deep end expecting you to understand it all as soon as you start playing. Now on to the good things about this game, the storyline, meh, I wouldn't say it's bad but it isn't the best MMORPG storyline I've ever played, gets really boring after about 1hr and a half and the combat system is great, exactly what you'd expect from an MMORPG game such as this. That's practically it, this game isn't worth the full price of £10.99, I got it in the sale at £2.74 and I still don't think it is worth it. If you're thinking about getting this game, check out 'Path of Exile' it is pretty much the same game but with a different aspect..also, it's free ;)!So unfortunately, i'm going to have to give this game a thumbs down, some people may or may not agree with my review but I think a lot of people do.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
BUYERS BEWARE! There are alot of issues and bugs with this game, in terms of technical status, it IS unfinished.I really wanted to enjoy this game, I really enjoyed Victor Vran so I was interested in The Adventures Of Helsing, despite the recent horrible reviews, I decided to give it a shot anyways. Boy, am I sorry I did! From te moment it booted up and I went to the video options to configure everything, I noticed that the most common and standard resolutions (1080p to 4k) were missing when using Direct X11. However, when I switched to Direct X9, those resolutions were suddenly available. Theere are 'guides' to try to find a 'solution', by creating CustomResolution.Cfg text file in the games local files, however none of things have worked for me or other people who have had this problem with the game. Actually it made the game worse, now textures were missing and the bugs within the game seemed to be magnified.Since that didn't work, I was told that I had to re-install Dirext X11, so I did. Nothing happened, perfmormance stayed the same, next the dev told me to try it on a different monitor to see if that helped so I ended up trying it on 3 different monitors and 2 different pc's, both pc's being pretty strong in specs. Nothing changed, I think the developer knew that none of tis would really help... as others before me seemed to have this problem and never got the issue resolved.Finally, I reached out to the community, someone told me that the problem wa son my end, which is pretty ignorant considering that (a.) I rarely have any problems with games - when I do, they're easily fixed (b.) Other people are having this problem, not just me. THen they told me that I should re-download the game 3 times - as if the game had some sort of superstitious ritual to make it work correctly. Let's look for a second at how ridiculous this is getting.Needless to say, I refunded the game and won't be trying it again... ever. I spent nearly an hour of trying to fix this game and running in circles like a chicken with my head cut-off. I've done .ini and compatability altering for games before, so I knew what I was doing, but this... GETTING THIS GAME TO WORK WAS THE REAL MONSTER I WAS TRYING TO SLAY! The poor optimiaztion and lack of ease of use made this a bad experience. I couldn't recommend this to anyone, even at the low price of $3.74, save your money for a game that actually works the way it should and supports your desired resolution.Yes, I know that it works right for some of you fanboys out there but there are far more people having problems with this game and I'm not just talking about the horrible Mac build, I'm on Windows! Git gud developers or go home!

content:
Posted: March 23
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a mildly fun medieval style RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously.  Call me a "filthy casual" if you will, but that sort of bugs me because it takes me out of the game a little bit. For example, the town portal system is called a "wishing well" a.l.a. Harry Potter with their magical fireplaces. So they make a joke about it saying that it is a fake & they should just call it a teleporter. I'm trying to get really into my medieval fantasy world here, guys! Why would you crack these little inside jokes like that. I get sort of a campy "Monty Python comedy sketch show" vibe from it. That is not a bad thing but it's just a different mentality I suppose.A positive aspect of the game is that it is sort of along the lines of Diablo II or Diablo 3 but is set in 1700's Transylvania, instead. That is well & good but for a guy who has a couple hundred hours into D2 & a hundred or two into D3, that doesn't cut anything & doesn't seem impressive or convincing in the least. Basically this game is a disappointment if you are looking for some sort of alternative to the Diablo franchise of RPG games from the company Blizzard, Inc, but better. I suppose it is ok for what it is. Not a popular game.Final conclusion can be summed up thusly: "Meh, it's OK." Not really a showstopper or barnburner or "game that changed the WORLD forever" or anything like that. The graphics are a bit dated. I haven't played a whole lot of the game. 6/10 would buy but only if it were HEAVILY discounted & there was nothing going on on a Saturday afternoon or Friday evening after working the ol' day job. It does go good with a Starbucks Latte, so that's something I guess. On second thought, save your money. DON'T buy the game reviewed here!

												Put on your wide-brimmed hat, grab your weapons and embark on an incredible adventure in the gothic-noir world of Borgovia, where mad science threatens the fragile peace between monster and mortal. Be Van Helsing, monster-hunter extraordinaire and save the day with your charming and beautiful companion, Lady Katarina (who happens to be a ghost, by the way). Explore the savage wilderness in the mountains and the soot-stained brick districts of a grim metropolis twisted by weird science, and don’t forget: you might never know who the real monsters are!

Posted: May 5, 2016
												Hunter is a decent class to play, but early on, the Thaumaturge, even on normal, is really boring, and difficult.. Slow single target spell casts, fighting packs of 5+ enemies.. The main attack can take 3 to 5 hits to kill each enemy.. The hunter on the other hand, has the ability to melee, or range.. Default melee swings, or gun shots.. I enjoyed the game playing as the Van Helsing iconic class (Hunter), but really dislike how the Thaumaturge (spell caster) plays..There also arent that many abilities that you will be able to use.. There is an overly confusing, andf cumbersome Rage meter, that is used to enhance each ability at the click of a button, for a single use.. Each ability can be enhanced with  up to 3 boosters, and are activated by pressing spacebar.. Its just too much to try to deal with in the heat of combat, and ive never used them.. They take up precious ability points in the skill tree, and even when i tried speccing into them, never used them at all.. You initialise the boost, then click whichever ability you want boosted (and which boosts you want), and its used in the very next ability.. Can be reinitialised until rage is empty.. Its just too cumbersome, and the button layout is pretty bad as well.. It is customizable atleast, but once in game, youll see what i mean.. Its soo many keys to hit.. I think each class has like 9 abilities to choose from, a dozen of so tricks, and some auras.. All of which require the same ability points to rank up, and you must start at the top of the trees, and work your way down.. You will be aquiring skills whether you intend to use them  or not, to get to the more powerful ones below.. The music is almost non existant, and the ambient sounds are your basic birds chirping, etc.. The lack of sounds also adds to the dull atmosphere, inevitebly putting you to sleep..I wont get into the "story" as its pretty pathetic, for what could have been amazing.. Its Van Helsing, afterall, and this is so generic, and this "Ink" just makes it worse.. I really dont have much good to say about this series.. I really would pass on it..Is really badly optimized.. Im far above recommended specs, and the game gets below 20fps often.. Skimming through the discussions, theres dozens of people asking for help with the same issue..It really pisses me off that i have to turn off all the deent settings to play this game, which isnt really great looking to begin with..All in all, i would say pass on it, unless you are a di hard arpg fan, and absolutely need another title... Because theres not enough of them apparently, lol..  Poor performance is the killer here..

Posted: June 14, 2014
												Not bad overall, but gets boring after a while. Diablo clones are hard to do right, because its all about balance. Balance between amount of items dropped, amount of monsters encountered, etc. Van Helsing almost nails it, but still lacks a few touches. For instance, the amount of monsters is just ridiculous! Some skills tend to be useless, while some are overpowered. There is nothing to tell about the plot. Its a huge cliche with cheesy Holywood lines. Waste not your time if your after it. There are some nice innovations - the tower defence mode in which hordes of monsters come is ingineous addition. Also, lVan Helsing is a solid choice for those who like Diablo clones, but not if you're not into the genre.

Posted: June 9, 2014
												The game is quite fun. A pretty typical hack-and-slash loot game, what makes it standout is the stellar voice acting. Certainly, Diablo 3 and Torchlight 2 are more polished as far as gameplay go, but this has the far superior storyline and characters.

Posted: June 10, 2014
												let me start by saying that this game is loaded with issues. This game uses all of the mechanics of torchlight... except that theres only one class unless you buy all the dlc. That said the single player drops loot for said dlc classes even when you arnt playing them, half of my epic drops were for the other two classes. Next although you can respec all your attribute points and skills there is no way for your to respec perks, and you dont know if you should wait because they are unlocked at certain attribute levels. they give you an ally but i found it best to put them in passive mode and suck up a third of the damage i took, as they die pretty easily even on the lower difficulties. the skill system encourages you to get only two active skills and put the rest into passives, auras, and tricks. by the end of the game i was a walking pile of passives with a single target ability, an aoe ability, and a heal. the game starts off a little boring, and continues that way until you reach the end, which luckily isnt very far as this game felt pretty short as i found myself skipping most enemies in the later levels just because i wanted it to be over. they added a rage system then discouraged me from using it by giving me buffs when i was full rage so i ignored the entire system which says that it was a bad system. in short this game is a bad copycat of torchlight with dumbed down skill trees and classes that you have to pay for. skip this game and go play torchlight.

Posted: August 20, 2013
												If you like games like Diablo II and Titan Quest, you will enjoy The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing.  As a dungeon crawler, it does a lot of things right, but falls short somewhat in the implementation of cooperative multiplayer.  Still, a very fun game to play on your own, thanks to the gothic environments and the engaging banter between the hero and his ghostly sidekick.

Posted: May 31, 2013
												The Incredibly Long Title of Van Helsing is a fun 10-12 hour (main campaign) hack and slashy romp. What's there is good, though the melee could use a bit more... oomfph.The skil tree is a bit shallow and some of the abilities don't scale too well at higher difficulties. While the power up system is a unique gimmick, it boils down either feeling too clunky to use on the fly or becoming an automated left or right click with the auto option turned on.The humor is very tongue-and-cheek and often breaks the fourth wall. Voice acting is pretty good overall with hilariously stereotypical vampire and mad scientist voices. Environments are well used. Even though you spend half your time in a forest, each one feels unique.The inventory management and itemization in this game is one of the best in this genre. A simple thing like automatically reorganizing if you pick up something and logically have the space to do so if not for one stupidly placed sword is a godsend.Overall if Van Helsing had a deeper and more complex skill tree along with a Newgame+ instead of just a pure endgame, this would be a worthy competitor to the big ARPGs. As it is now, it's still a decent romp for its price.

Posted: June 15, 2013
												'Adventures of...' is pure-blood ARPG by every means, featuring lots of loot, the companion, magic, item sets, potions, side quests, several difficulty levels from very easy to insane, monsters, monsters, more monsters, a skill tree and a level cap which will never allow you to fully develop your character in one pass. Relatively short unless you not try to beat it at any difficulty above normal, the game however is quite enjoyable. So if you just want to sacrifice several free hours of your precious life to play with regular meat grinder, you're welcome.

Posted: September 13, 2013
												Set in the supernatural world of steampunk monster hunting, you play as one of the "nameless" offspring of the legendary monster hunter Van Helsing. Aided by your companion, a ghost named Lady Katarina, the two of you work together to try and find out what causes such strife in the land of Borgovia, and how you can solve the issues of the folks there plagued by dark horrors.Do not buy this game for the combat, graphics or anything like it. You're really only buying it for two reasons: Multiplayer, and the dialogue between Helsing and Lady Katarina. Beyond that, nothing interesting.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												Let me start off with by telling you what type of game The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is; its an ARPG. This is similar to  games such as Diablo and Torchlight. So essentially, top down camera, lots of monsters, and most importantly lots and lots of loot. So why should you get this game. Van Helsing takes elements from many different sources in the fantasy and science fiction genres. The includes everything from Lord of the Rings to Monty Python for fantasy and Star Wars to Hitchicker's Guide to the Galaxy for science fiction. This is a game that knows its target audience very well and caters to them, but not so much as to take away from the actual game. Still you will notice nods to different things and they fit within the theme of the game very well. The gameplay is very solid, but it may take some getting used to if you don't play this game very often. It still uses WASD just not for movement, you use only the mouse for movement and attacks. However it is pretty intuitive and takes no time to get used to. The mobs you fight are a bit of challenge and you will die quite often in the early stages but its enjoyable to get better as the game progresses. To summarize this game was made with the thought of the player in mind and it really shows in the final product. There are some bugs here and there but the developers, Neocore Games, is very responsive to player issues and timely with patches. If you are on the fence about getting this I would reccomend this game to anyone who is up for a good adventure.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game is AWESOME! It feels like Diablo 2  with a smattering of Sacred mixed in for effect while still managing to be its own game. The custamization could use some additional options but once you are in the midst of playing it's not a big deal.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												While the story writing isn't the worst and some of the banter is amusing...this game is really just not all that fun unless you very much enjoy the mindless repetition of hack and slashing over and over with giant packs of enemies that require little to no strategy to defeat with the right build. The biggest downside and the reason I wouldn't recommend it, is it crashing frequently. To each their own, the game itself wasn't too bad, it just didn't manage to keep my attention.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Maybe not a got Mac port?This is not an easy review, because I like the game. It is fun, when it works. But here is already the problem. I experienced graphic problems, crashes and sometimes the game slows down for not so obvoius reasons. Before you read on, please note, I have friends who played this game without any problems. I therefore assume that this might be a problem just for Mac users. My computer is an iMac and shouldn’t have any problems to run this game. Still I had plenty of problems in the short time I own this game.Do not get me wrong. When it works it is fun and I think the story is fine. Sure the game does reminds you of Diablo 3 a lot, but it is in my opinion also unique enough to be different from it.I got the game in a sale for just $6.50 so I am not to disappointed, still sad I couldn’t finish the story at least once. To many problems for me to keep trying.My recommendation is therefore not easy. I would like to give it a thumbs up, but unfortunately I can't. You might be fine when you are a PC user. As mentioned, my friends who own this game on PC were not running into any problems. I, on the other hand, as Mac user had lots of them.

Posted: April 14, 2014
												Was the Diablo series one of your favorite games in the early 2000's? Do you like steampunk? Gothic monsters? Parodoxical references to literature and pop-culture? If any--or, especially, all--of these questions have a positive answer, this game is for you. It features witty voiced banter between a monster hunter and his ghostly companion, levels of damage that could be considered "Too Damn High" and quite an array of interesting monsters. The main storyline is about 15-20 hours long, depending how effecient you are at killing things, filled with traditional hack-and-slash murder, plus a couple tower defence scenarios. While the story is a bit short, there are scenarios for higher-level players, with bigger and better loot, and also a never-ending story mode, which starts you back at the beginning, just with tougher monsters, better items, and even moar damage.If you're looking for a ARPG with good replay value, decent mechanics, and some cool gimicks, this is the game for you. (Even more so because of its price tag. $20 for the game +all dlc)

Posted: April 10, 2014
												Remember back in the 90s when you would still discover new things about the characters you played halfway through the game? The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing takes you back to those days. The skill-and ability systems are layered and complex and will require you to think them through and test them out thoroughly. Even on normal mode, this game is a challenge, even more so when you are joined by friends. For some players this complexity will be a turn-off, but for others it will be a welcome challenge.Great design, over-the-top but funny voice-acting and a nice challenge for those who wish it.
