Posted: September 25, 2013
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is an action role-playing video game Diablo clone that focuses on the trials of young Van Helsing and has nothing to do with the movie of the same name. It is set in a fictional gothic-noir steampunk 19th-century Eastern Europe.Graphics wise, while it will not be taking any awards, it is still pleasing to look at, and quite atmospheric looking especially when portraying the haunted misty looking fictional eastern european forests. The character models however look quite crude. In short, the graphics is serviceable, but unremarkable.Gameplay for the main campaign will take about 13 hours depending on your playstyle and is basically the same as most other Diablo Clones. It borrows alot of the mechanics and ideas from other games especially from the Torchlight series in its use of Pets. Instead of having pets in this game however, you will have a female ghost companion called Lady Katarina who not only helps you sell items like the pets in Torchlight, you can actually level her up as a very formidable helper who is surprisingly very useful in the game.Another interesting part is a mini tower defence game at the later part of the game, which I thought was quite refreshing as I have not yet seen any Action RPGs that adds this mode yet. While it doesn't really add much to the game, and only serves as a side distraction, it is a nice addition.Music consists mostly of slow and sombre pieces which complements its setting very well, and is competently done. Voice work for both Van Helsing and Katarina is competent and i enjoyed their witty banter with each other. The voice work for the other NPCs however feels like they're overacting most of the time, trying very hard to fake that Eastern European accent.Now as for the downsides, the backstory of the game is very unremarkable and completely forgettable. While other games of this genre also suffer the same issues storywise, for some reason, I just cannot immerse myself into this game. Maybe its because the game doesn't take itself seriously or maybe its the fact that for a game called "Van Helsing" you never actually get into a combat with a single Vampire, not even the last boss is a vampire. (Actually there is only 1 vampire in the entire game, and he's only a friendly NPC.)Enemy AI are also very simplistic, and most of the time, the game's only challenge is to simply throw lots of creeps in huge group at your face forcing you to kite 90% of the time.Loot is very bland and lacks in variation visually. It seems that there are only a very limited selection of items that visually alters your characters and most of them just look the same as any other.The other bad point is unfortunately the overall play control which is especially bad because play control is probably the most important aspect of any Action RPGs. While this game allows the use of WASD movement via keyboard (probably one of the rare ones that allow this), the execution is just downright terrible. Example: Lets say if you were to try to move in one direction, then press the Shift key to stand in place and attack incoming mobs, the next time you release the keys, you may actually find the character automatically continue to move forward on his own and can only stop when you press the corresponding movement key. More then once this caused me to die unnecessary deaths because I simply couldn't move away from mobs when they start swarming me. This bug also seems to happen if you use only mouse clicks to move, and is extremely frustrating and almost destroys what enjoyment i had from the game. There is also a Co-op mode, but I haven't had a chance to try that with a friend so I cannot comment about if it functions well or not.Overall Rating: 6.0 / 10An average Action RPG, while not as polished or as refined as the Torchlight or Diablo Series, does show some promise. Its worth a look if you can get it at a cheap sale. The movement bug I mentioned in the review is really very frustrating and I hope that they can get it resolved soon.

I loved it, and wanted to keep playing.  I hope they continue to expand this game, which I believe they could.  If you liked Torchlight and Torchlight 2, this is a must have for you.  The minion dynamic and game feel is very similar, but she is a lot more fun than a dog.  I tend to play my games with the sound off, but found myself turning it on so I could hear her banter.A definite fun game, well worth the money.

												The game plays similarly to other ARPG's such as the Diablos and Path of Exile. The story is unique in the sense that it draws strongly from the Van Helsing lore and the steampunk styling of it doesn't appear in many other ARPG's. The game is still quite buggy as there are many skills that quite inbalanced (looking at you fire pillar and electro ball) and some classes are definitely better than others but it seems that the developers are still actively pushing out updates and fixes. Definitely worth getting and playing through if you're interested in the styling of the game, the story, or are a big fan of ARPG's but don't expect it to be a perfectly polished product.

Posted: September 5, 2014
												After playing 10 + hours, I guess that I'm able to judge this game.The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is hack n slay RPG in the style of Diablo or Torchlight.I recommened this to you if you like those kind of games! It has some good things like the skill system and different kinds of enemys. Plus you have 95 achievments to unlock, of which the most are quite easy but some are also quite challenging. Also it isn't too expensive and it is definitely worth its price, especially if you're getting it during a sale.What I also like about it is the overall world and the atmosphere, plus it has some humor in it which will probably make you smirk from time to time.Plus the game is quite player friendly, you're able to reset your skills easily for Van Hellsing and Katharina and identifying items doesn't require a spell (which lead to the question why they actually implemented that feature because now you're only required to right-click and wait 2 seconds)Things I don't like are for example the huge hordes of enemies you can encounter. Although the battles are fun (which is important because this the main thing you're doing) I was sometimes feeling like the developers just smashed as much enemies as possible in an area which sometimes leads to exhausting long battles against 30 or more enemies at a time. Also, the story isn't really exciting but that doesn't matter that much in that kind of genre. Graphics are also quite good and support the atmosphere of the game.All in all: 78/100, worth buying!

Posted: September 1, 2014
												TIA of Van Helsing is a surprising game. The maps and the enemies are very well made and it is obvious to me that the creators paid a lot of attention to details. However, while scoring high on the graphics I would say that the gameplay is somehow mediocre. It doesn't give that thrill the way Torchlight does and is not quite as diverse(loot) as Dungeon Siege or Titan Quest (btw even if the game is huge ~20gb it is nowhere near as long as TQ). The loot is a bit disappointing mainly because there are not many types of items, most having the same name with slightly different bonuses. The skills don't offer very rewarding fights (I played as a mage and hunter) and might actually be the main gameplay issue.I know I have pointed the negative aspects of the game, but that is only because there are already a bunch of amazing games in this genre. It still proves to be an addictive game with reasonably good storyline and very good dialogues especially between Lady Katarina and Van Helsing. It is also one of the few games which is reasonably priced.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												Torchlight 2 is a lot better and has better replay abillity. Skill balance is just lame. Overall game balance is really weak. Last boss extremally easy. Gold drops and prices just make no sense since you can get 100,000gold within one short run and upgrades cost 5-10k gold (which is said to be a lot)12-15 hours gameplay and it's all the same since level one. Fight tons of mobs constantly. AoE AoE AoE. You will have max 4 skills. No quick spell changing. Power up only on active 2 skills LMB+RMB, which makes no sense with other skills you use. (4) Leveling up skills > anything else.Not really worth the money. If you like this type of games you'll love VanHellsing, however the plot is weak, no end game, no real open space, Hit and run AoE spam all game long. Fun for max 8 hours then becomes a boring SPAM 1 skill and run game.Comparison to Torchlight 2 :+ better graphics+ fun power-up system- item-readabillity (T2 lot better)- experiance grid (leveling is really slow after 28)- no plot really- no end game thank you or anything- 15 hours gameplay vs 80 hours gameplay (T2)- HORDES OF MOBS NON-STOP makes game boring- Gold balance is extremaly bad- Stats/skills balance is bad- DLC sadness.

Posted: February 17, 2014
												The Future Generations of what we used to know as kids- Diablo Game.In this great graphics game, you will never feel bored or that alone playing it as this is mainly a single payer game.What makes it this way is all thanks to the character development of the katarina 'ghost' who follows you around and assist you in battles. She was designed to be a humorous and engaging companion throughout this game. The voice accent and story is quite well planned out. Its her interaction with you that makes the game a whole new level unlike in diablo where you wander around in the woods with yourself and your erm, mud monsters who doesn't talk.I started with the complete pack demo kit on 'normal' mode'. Which was great since the monster aren't too overpowering that might make you give up playing the game. Afterall, you wanna just enjoy playing & finish the game story not engraging yourself trying so hard to kill the monsters. Or actually, them killing you. Another great thing is that you can respawn on the same spot you died by paying 'coins'. Gone are the days where dying means restarting the whole mission and having to walk all the way back for the same battle. In saying this , note that you will be a invisible ghost for few seconds, allowing you to move around before respawning as a human and meanwhile still being chased by the monsters that once killed you before...Weapons & skills are fun & have a pretty acceptable range to choose from. The abilitys and skills are too not advanced nor complicated, to me as a 21 years old (Girl) gamer.  Another plus point.Recommended for people who don't want to go for the games that is too addictive such as team fortess which you can play hours after hours trying to kill people without any objective really. For somewho like me who have a full time job commitment but is a young adult that would like to enjoy a simple yet satisfing & engaging game, this is the one. P.S i searched so hard on steam & finally found it <3P.S [Part 2] I finished the game within two weeks. So i must say the story is kinda short. And there is not point purchasing those arcane classes stuff. Becos there isnt really a 'never ending story'. They said that becos in reality , it means restarting the game with different class but same map, monester & story. And God, that is boring as hell!!

Posted: January 30, 2014
												A surprisingly enjoyable hack n' slash aRPG experience. Steals many of the best ideas from the Diablo and Torchlight series, and adds its own unique twists. It's from a Hungarian developer, and shows some obvious signs of its n0t-astronomical budget: some janky animations and snaggy terrain textures, terrible voice acting for minor characters (caveat: the voice work for the main characters is actually quite good), and a rough looking (and feeling) UI. However, the game redeems itself with its creative combat and level design, surprisingly good art direction, and plot/dialogue which vaccilates from serious to snarky to self-effacing. An aRPG that takes itself seriously, but not TOO seriously. Worth a playthrough if you're fond of the genre.

Apparently that was it. Only thing left to do is maybe play on a harder level or treasure hunt or achievement hunt.I also thought that the mechanics of not being able to re-kill bosses in the story mode was a bit strange and you would have to go into endless story or something. Posted: November 3, 2015
												I started playing this game because I didn't really feel like playing Diablo 3, and all in all I'm pretty happy with my choice.Story:I was expecting the game to be a Diablo-clone in most ways, so having the big bad be a  instead of a  was a pretty nice surprise. Fighting robots(?) in a steampunk-ish world also felt a bit fresh compared to fighting the same old demons and mythological creatures (some of which do appear in this game as well). The basic story is of course the good old "hack your way through a bunch of enemies to defeat the big bad trying to take over the world (or country?)", but there's nothing wrong with that.Gameplay:If you have played Diablo or any other ARPG you will probably recognize the play style right away. You use your mouse and a couple of buttons to dash out various spells while keeping an eye on your health and mana. The addition of rage, which refills when you kill a creature and can be used to power up your spells, was a nice touch. It gives you an extra thing to do during fights, as well as more ways to personalize your skill tree, so an extra plus there.Graphics:The graphics were fine. Not great, not bad. Some creatures looked pretty good, some looked pretty bland. The same can be said for the environment. Personally I enjoyed the city zones more than the nature zones. The (few and short) cut scenes were pretty meh, especially compared to the Diablo cut scenes, but that's acceptable.Music:While playing the game I thought that the music fit the mood pretty well, but as soon as I stopped playing I forgot the soundtrack right away.The voice acting in this game... At first I thought that the voice acting was just really, really bad, and almost lol'ed a couple of times during the first few hours of the game. But then I realized that that was what they were going for (probably?). Sort of cheesy, over-the-top voice acting, that when you get used to it fit the game really well, and was sometimes just really funny (in a good way!). Some of the comments from both Van Helsing and Lady Katarina were just hilarious, although by the end of the game Katarina was becoming quite annoying.Overall:Overall I enjoyed this game, even my second playthrough, which was a little unexpected. I don't really want to call Van Helsing a Diablo-clone, since there were a couple of things that set it apart from Diablo, so let's just call it a decent option if you like ARPGs. I recommend this game, even at full price if you don't want to wait for a sale, however I do have a couple of warnings:1. There are some bugs in the game, the most common being corpses stuck in walls or terrain that can't be looted. I also found a couple of chests that I couldn't open for whatever reason. The biggest bug I faced was a door leading to the next zone being closed, forcing me to start over with a new character. (Luckily this didn't happen with my hardcore heroic character.) There was a fix posted on the developer's forum to fix this, but that fix didn't work for me. On July 2nd 2015 they added the "Mantis Bug Tracker" to the game, which should help fix more bugs, but I wasn't able to test this out myself.2. If you care about achievements you can get most of the achievements by playing through the game twice. None of them are really that hard to get, as my first playthrough was on hardcore heroic difficulty (=perma-death), and I only died four times, so the game is fairly easy. However, there is one achievement that is just plain stupid. It requires you to get 500,000 kills, which is a lot, seeing as you only get about 10,000-15,000 kills per playthrough. Luckily there is a way to make Lady Katarina afk farm kills for you, which she is doing for me as I am typing this, but just be aware that there is this one really annoying achievement if you (like me) want to clear the game 100%.But all in all, a really good game.

Posted: December 22, 2014
												Summary: Guide Van Helsing the famous monster-slayer through a tounge and cheek adventure killing baddies and looting corspses.Time until completion: 15 hours.Pros: - A pretty game.- Controls well. KB/M or gamepad.- Servicable enough story that doesnt take itself too seriously.  It even throws in some pop culture references i giggled at now and then.- Loot.- Fun skillsCons:- Camera. The camera is static and the geometry never becomes transparent in the slightest if your character goes behind it. - Crafting. While you can combine runes to make new runes or slot runes in weapons, it in no way tells you what you can or cant combine. It just leaves you constantly trying combinations until something works.  This made me basically just never use it.- Skill tree. While the skills themselves are fine, the max level is 30 and you have to have certain skills to unlock others. Because of this, there is simply no way you can diversify your skills if you want to be effective by the endgame. It seems like the max level should be almost double so you can actually use all the skills. You can reset them and re-allocate them, but you are still limited to so many points going into all skills.- Difficulty spikes.  Probably my biggest complaint.  There were so many times i would just be almost 1 hot killed going into a wave of enemies. It never seemed like there was an alternative way to approach these situations.  You simply die and re-start at the last checkpoint (or base) and keep hacking away at the same group of enemies until they die. This seemed silly. I thought I would be recommending this, but I find it hard to with the difficulty issues in particular. You would be better off playing Titan Quest or another APRG that is better balanced.Overall, I would give this a 60% or so.  The few issues I have really impacted the game too much.

Posted: September 13, 2013
												Set in the supernatural world of steampunk monster hunting, you play as one of the "nameless" offspring of the legendary monster hunter Van Helsing. Aided by your companion, a ghost named Lady Katarina, the two of you work together to try and find out what causes such strife in the land of Borgovia, and how you can solve the issues of the folks there plagued by dark horrors.Do not buy this game for the combat, graphics or anything like it. Posted: January 4, 2014
												Let me start off with by telling you what type of game The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is; its an ARPG. This is similar to  games such as Diablo and Torchlight. So essentially, top down camera, lots of monsters, and most importantly lots and lots of loot. So why should you get this game. Van Helsing takes elements from many different sources in the fantasy and science fiction genres. The includes everything from Lord of the Rings to Monty Python for fantasy and Star Wars to Hitchicker's Guide to the Galaxy for science fiction. This is a game that knows its target audience very well and caters to them, but not so much as to take away from the actual game. Still you will notice nods to different things and they fit within the theme of the game very well. The gameplay is very solid, but it may take some getting used to if you don't play this game very often. It still uses WASD just not for movement, you use only the mouse for movement and attacks. However it is pretty intuitive and takes no time to get used to. The mobs you fight are a bit of challenge and you will die quite often in the early stages but its enjoyable to get better as the game progresses. To summarize this game was made with the thought of the player in mind and it really shows in the final product. There are some bugs here and there but the developers, Neocore Games, is very responsive to player issues and timely with patches. If you are on the fence about getting this I would reccomend this game to anyone who is up for a good adventure.

												After debating back and forth many times, this game cannot be recommened. Even with notable RPG elements, there was always a promient drawback. It is very obvious there is a lack of skill and character variation. The maximum level is 30 which greatly restricts the overall gameplay, making combat EXTREMELY repetitive. Sadly, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is not the game that will reimburse its buyers with endless hours of enjoyment. ARPG fans will find a much better experience with other similar, but much better, titles such as Torchlight II.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Brief review:The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a really solid action-RPG with the same level of polish and story as other post-Diablo 2 games in the genre such as Titan Quest and Path of Exile. Highlights for me were:* The power-up system that had you do a little more thinking about what buttons to press when;* Your companion, Lady Katarina, who not only offers more customisation options, but also provides grin-worthy banter with your protagonist; and* The various design decisions that lead to a much more streamlined ARPG experience, including being able to toggle monster respawn, sending Katarina back to town to sell weapons, the 'sell all' and 'organise' inventory buttons, and much more.Recommended for any fans of the Diablo series that were disappointed with D3 and are looking for a cheap, well-themed alternative (and don't want to be part of the hardc0re ARPG scene with Path of Exile).Podcast:To hear a podcast with extended impressions on this game, tune in to its episode onTim and Phill Talk About Games: http://www.timandphill.com/2013/12/24/taptag-006-bram-stokers-brains-edition/

Posted: January 30, 2014
												A surprisingly enjoyable hack n' slash aRPG experience. Steals many of the best ideas from the Diablo and Torchlight series, and adds its own unique twists. It's from a Hungarian developer, and shows some obvious signs of its n0t-astronomical budget: some janky animations and snaggy terrain textures, terrible voice acting for minor characters (caveat: the voice work for the main characters is actually quite good), and a rough looking (and feeling) UI. However, the game redeems itself with its creative combat and level design, surprisingly good art direction, and plot/dialogue which vaccilates from serious to snarky to self-effacing. An aRPG that takes itself seriously, but not TOO seriously. Worth a playthrough if you're fond of the genre.

Posted: November 4, 2013
												I have played PoE Beta, Torchlight 1 & 2, Diablo 1, 2 and 3. This game beats them all except for maybe Diablo 2 with Expansion during its heyday. Van Helsing is fun and unique with witty dialogue and snappy writing. You actually get rewarded for exploring your entire map. The loot is fun (no AH). You can play offline if it's just single player. You can also play online (public or steam friends only) with up to 4 people in co-op (password or sans). Your companion picks up stuff like potions, crafting mats and different levels of unique or common gear depending on how you set her. She can also be sent to town to sell, as well as buy a specifically designated number of potions; She's sassy too. You have enchanting as well as alchemy for upgrading your gear. You make decisions in dialogue even that impact your gameplay more true to table-top role playing games! Yes, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is addictive and yes, the story is fun. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys top-down action rpgs. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is what Diablo 3 should have been.[ Also, I just go the DLC tonight and I am enjoying my Arcane Mechanic, which can be played with pets. I have yet to try the Thaumargist (sp?), which appears to be a steampunk version of a mage. I do like the steampunkish feel of hte game. The artwork is quite good. ]

Posted: September 1, 2013
												Weird little title I picked up at half price. I've played maybe a 1/3rd of the game, not 100% sure. The game's massive size of 20 gigs would imply thre is a lot of content. Here's the Pros: Good Aesthetic, clearly steampunk but not in a funky sort of way because they don't just add cogs to crap. A top hat, is well, just a top hat. A gun is a gun. No need to add a bunch of wierd junk to it! Gameplay is intense, without feeling like you're going to get gibbed the next second and can course correct if things start going downhill. (Negative on Diablo 3.) Story is simple, but fun type. You're the son of the legendary monster hunter, which has a Dutch name but lives in England... who's been called back into service to hunt down not monsters, but mad scientists in an Eastern European country. It's simple, but they keep the narrative up through the story. I'll mark this up for: It's a hack and slash RPG. Diablo 3 did better, but Torchlight 2 story lacks an clear overarching goal (Kill... the alchemist maybe?) that makes the game difficult to play after a while. Finally, the companion is optional. If you don't want her to particpate, you can turn her passive which gives a passive bonus and all her auras, but she doesn't particpate and you can just act like she's not there. Also, the game understands it swaps you with guys and provides you with ample abilities to counter that. Cons: I'll say the skill tree is limited. Very limited. There's about four viable paths, and two sets of focuses. Ranged or Melee, each with a physical and magical option. I think there's a mixed physical/magical option down the center, which would imply a third tree. If you could play as maybe other famous monster hunters or characters from the period it might help! Voice Acting is... sub-par. Not abysmal, thankfully the two main characters, Katarina has an acceptable voice actor and Van Helsing's is actually decent. I could listen to the dude talk at me for a while! THe villagers just seem unmotive. The Vampire's voice actor is worth a few lols at how overthe top he is. I will admit I do like the voice acting on the Robot-Line Infantry. They sound approiately distorted yet mechanical for magical robots. Music: Is there music? I don't know, I don't remember it well. I'd say that's a problem, because when I love music. I love it, a lot, I don't forget it! So clearly not much there. Weapons are limited to swords (Two hander or dual wielding) and guns (Rifles, shotguns, or Dual Wield pistols). I think that's more to do with Van Helsing lore and his training, but still, again, limitation of ability isn't a positive in a game like this.

Posted: August 18, 2015
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is not a long game, about 15 hours or so all up to complete the storyline, but it is time well spent in my opinion.  In a nutshell, you are the son of the famous monster hunter and vampire slayer, who answers a call for help (sent to your father) from the fictional eastern european country of Borgovia.  Van Helsing travels with the Lady Katarina, a ghost bound to the family's service and it's the byplay between these two characters that I extremely well done.  While Katarina assists Van Helsing in combat with her abilities (which can be upgraded and new ones learned as the game progresses), she also has a number of things to say about Van Helsing's actions (as guided by the player) throughout the game.  There are some wonderful lines she comes out with that made me laugh.  There are also a number of references to other things (Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy being one of them), all of which are neatly tied into the narrative.  The game does finish on a cliffhanger after you confront the mad scientist, so if this game does appeal, you will probably want to invest in the second and third installments to continue the story.   As for mechanics, it's pretty simple and straight forward.  I used a controller and for the most part had no issues though there is one thing that I feel was badly designed.  The D pad has 4 functions, down to bring up the map, left and right to use a healing or mana potion and up to teleport to the current "home base".  The first time I teleported I had no idea what I'd done (or that I'd managed to hit up on the D pad).  Once I'd worked out what was happening, it became a bit of a bugbear in the middle of combat - go to drink a healing potion, miss and next thing you know you've teleported back to base.  While at times it got me out of a nasty fight, it was frustrating, so it's something to be aware of and you may want to investigate changing the keybind to either the Left Trigger or Bumper.Overall I really enjoyed The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing, it had a good mix of environments, an engaging narrative with good characters, particularly Katarina who is think was just brilliant.  There aren't any puzzles to tax your mind, but if you are looking for something where you can check your brain, hack and slash your way around Borgovia and have a ghost pick on you, then I highly recommend it.

(hozáteszem maga a 2 dlc drágább egyenként mint a maga a játék),Nem baj mindegy lehet ettől még jó nem? hát nem, következő hibák 2013 ban megjellent játék-ban nehogy már netudjanak egy-egy szörny/ember/valami -ből legalább 3 fajtát csinálni.. szégyen jön 2millió ugyanolyan ember Klón megölni egy harcban. Pazar az a tény is hogy minimális animációk vannak 3 féle ütés + 6 féle varázslat.... ÉS a Magyar fejlesztésű játékba nem fért bele Magyar szinkrón de MÉG EGY NORMÁLIS MAGYAR FELIRAT SEM. Anyám elnézést de mi az hogy félig magyar félig nem ??? a szöveg közepén angol az előt meg utána meg Magyar?? Úristen, a játék elvileg online Játokot is tudd de ezt felejtsük el mert azon kivül hogy néha müködik néha bemongya a halált ,... ha még is sikerül elindulni akkor is ROHADTUL BUGOS, Igy 2 év távlatában is amikor megvettük 2 -en a haverommal a 3 . küldin nem tudtunk tovább menni mert a bug nem engedte ,,, az adott szőrny csoport amit lekellett volna kaszálni mindig újá éllet és az ami előidézte meg 3 millio HP-ja volt. (akkor még kb 20-akat csapsz) Singleplayerbe tovább lehet menni igaz.. de multiba nem és ez nem mentség .. és amikor kikerültük külön-külön singlibe ezt a buggot akkor meg egy másik jőt. Az online funkció "Uslees" . Singlibe is rengetek bug van az átvezetők elcsusznak mintha tört játékkal játszanék.A karakter fellet a a felirat elcsuszik a kamera fekete kockákat mutatt -- olykor nem látn isemmit. Azon kivűl egy - egy pozitivum ,hogy az Angol szinkron király és a párbeszédek sem rosszak.. de ez egyszerüen nem elég. Vannak secretek de azok inkább unalmasak mint érdekesek. Már javítani tuti nem fogják szóval ezt érdemes hagyni. A 2. résszel nem játszottam azt hallotam az nagyon jó lett . De ezt az élményt kihagytam volna. Még ugyis hogy mind össze 5 dolláromba azaz kemény 1000 per száz FT-ba fájt a game. hiába Magyar fejleszésű egyszerüen ez sajnálatos... Nem értem miért vagyok én az első aki ez leírja..

Posted: January 3, 2016
												I can say after giving this game and it's sequel the old college try that I cannot recommend this game. At first, the game was light and funny, but the big aspect of this game (what with being a diablo clone) is combat, and if you are lacking in that aspect, then the rest of your game is going to suffer; and that is almost exactly what happened to this game. The game is quite laggy almost all the time, and the game swarms you with so many enemies with so much health that fighting them feels like trying to knock out a mountain with nothing but a toothpick. I'm not saying that fights should be easy, but even on normal mode, trash mobs take way too much damage before they go down, and more attacks should have more effective AOE.I chose to play as a ranged character after giving the game a few early tries, and found I was nothing but frustrated. Enemies which were basically living artillery were able to instakill me as soon as they saw me, and I found myself running around like a madman taking 5-8 shots to take out a single enemy which had 20 others just like it right behind. In brief, combat was long, tedious and I would see future mobs coming at me not with the glee of popping their heads off, but with resignation as they were just another obstacle between me and my final goal. An obstacle which, I had wiped out at least 12 of in the past play session.In short: Even after putting all my skillpoints into body and dex, I still didn't have enough health to survive encounters, or enough damage to make fighting monsters not feel like a chore. In Diablo, I can wipe out a dungeon in 15 minutes on high torment levels. In this game, I'd be lucky to wipe out a map section in what feels like three times that.And as a final tip to the developer: writing achievements is fine, but DO NOT make an achievement that says "Don't kill a monster type" in a game where you have been patting my back for killing everything that moves, then putting that monster type all over the map, then having them attack me with flamethrowers doing an insubstantial amount of damage, and when I do kill it not allow me to go back and un-kill that monster. Same goes for that "Fight the final boss without destroying any spawn towers", because I sustain Fulmugati will be almost indestructible if you don't.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												I decided to play The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing after viewing the trailer, and getting some exhaustion from Diablo III and Torchlight 2. This one seemed to be a decent Hack & Slash, with a nice twist regarding the setting of central Europa and possibly legions of blood-sucking foes.In this game, you play a single character, Van Helsing, who is followed by a ghostly teammate, Katarina. You don't have to choose a class before playing, and just develop your character along the way, using several skill trees.Basically, you can eradicate a significant amount of monsters by using either a sword or a gun. Each weapon has its specific skill tree with numerous styles of slashes and shots. Each one can be leveled up, or customized with additional powers, triggered by Rage. Also, you can wander in the side of magic by learning strikes blending physical and magical damage, even pure magical damage. If not enough, you can learn passive abilities and active spells, that can take advantage of some specific situations or simply save your butt - leaving you with a fair amount of combinations to craft.The amount of damage you do or can endure is proportional to basic weapon and armor stats, plus the different levels of your character stats and skills, combined with the multiple bonuses you can get from gear. Very similar to Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2. So don't fall in love with that particular weapon or gear if the next one is seamingly up a notch, the impact could be tremendous.On top of that, your translucent female sidekick is not only witty, but can be used either as a melee fighter, a ranged shooter or a decent support. She also can level up and has her own gear and skill tree to become a tactical partner or a stat multiplier.At this point, it's pretty clear that this game targets an audience that loves to analyse how hundred skills relate to each other, carefully crafting the most badass character possible, something like "hit once, obliterate many". It's a good thing to have a significant amount of depth that way (remember Titan Quest !) but for me it was just like "too much". So I decided to focus on a restricted number of skills, low enough to keep me focused on the actual map cleaning.The game is linear, with some quests on the side. The levels are not really beautiful but varied, and the enemies compensate lack of intelligence by sheer number. Luckily, the dialog between Van Helsing and Katarina are funny so you can have a good time playing them.Something that kinda puzzled me was the introduction of a micro-game of Tower Defense. Not that it wasn't interesting or refreshing, but it seemed that the developers decided to put everything remotely cool in the game, thus pushing it in the Land of Blended Genre where chances of survival are slim. Luckily, the Tower Defense micro-game is nicely done, but too much thin for consideration. Overall, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a good Hack & Slash, that can satisfy seasoned players, but could be daunting to newcomers.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												For the genre of ARPG this game stands out among those like Path of Exile and Torchlight as the spiritual successors to Diablo 2.   What makes this game more unique is its story, and its skill system.   It takes the story of Van Helsing and throws you into the very midst of a gothic era where monsters rule the landscape.    With only the basic class to choose from unless you get DLC there isn't much variety in the terms of classes, but in my opinion the DLC is worth the price because it gives you two other, very unique classes to play that give a very distinct flavor to the game with each class you play.  With a full fledged multiplayer system, friends make this game even more enjoyable as you go on a monster hunting romp through a forest with your buddies.All in all, 8/10. Would Play.

												Me and hubby bought this whilst it was on sale.I do like my hack 'n' slash games, i loved Diablo 2 with its expansion LoD loved that so much i have two copies.. original disks and the battle chest... but as i was saying i do like the HnS genre so when hubs saw this and even he was interested in it, i was like yup get it!Its fun, the story line is awesome, the mobs are interesting to say the least all be it short but it has replay value, thank goodness for no random map generator and the fact you can turn OFF mob spawns so when you return to an area you dont have to deal with the pesky buggers again.Sometimes the dialog is a little squiffy IE sounds like some of the NPC voices where bored as sin reading there script, but VH's voice is delish, Kats quips are funny, and the amount of references through out the game play is friggin awesome!All in all i do recommend this game. Posted: May 20, 2015
												This game is a shame. It starts quite well, but as soon as you are progressing through the game, the flaws appear very clearly.The maps are very small and therefore, instead of creating more areas, the devs have favored the overfilling of the few maps with thousands of monsters. Yes that's true it's a H&S, but in this game the maps are literally overcrowded by unimaginative packs of monsters.Second disappointment is when your realize that the game mechanics are botched up : adding strength also add life (good for melee fighters). If you choose to play as ranged characters, you'll have to split your stats between dexterity (ranged) and strength (for not being insta-killed by the endless swarms mentioned above), and therefore preventing your ranged character to dispatch efficiently the monsters (who are packed tight).Therefore the game is heavily favored and unbalanced at best. Combat versus the final boss is also a freaking pain to play : you have to run around in circles for literally 20 minutes (check the videos on youtube), praying that the boss and the sarm of werewolves-on-steroids will not one-shot you, as you can't save during this combat.Avoid this game by all cost, this deceiving game is not worth your trouble.

												It's a good game and for the price you can't really go wrong. Don't expect anything genrebreaking. But it is thoroughly enjoyable. The surroundings are pretty beautiful and diverse, although the graphics are not amazing. But thats okay for a ARPG. The battle system is pretty funny, there are a lot of different skills and attacks and auras. There are a lot of diverse enemies with a lot of different skills, but still you dont really need different tactics to defeat them. I play as a ranged character and basically you just shoot the enemies and run circles around them, most engagements can be won very easily, and even if you should have problems, you can buy infinite potions and you will have a looooot of money. (Like every game really, i don't understand why there never is a game where money is scarce). The game is missing a real tutorial, in the beginning there are a lot of things you will not immediately understand, but after some hours you will. But yeah, 10€ for well over 10 hours of good gameplay should be a no-brainer.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												Because there was only two recomendations for the game, yes or no, i couldn't express a mixed view. A good game but there are some really anoying element to be aweare of. The first is you can't have a break from the game half way through a level. If for example you exit from the game half way through the level, switch off the comp and them go back to it later then all the monster you've killed are back there again. It means you're pratically starting the level from scratch and that is very annoying. All your previous good work gone to waste. Second. Some of the protals, actually most of the portals, drop you right in the middle of a horde to monsters and you usually get slaughtered because there are so many. This is partially caused by the provious problem but could be solved by not having any monsters around the portal.The third. It takes so long for VanHelsing to regenerate HPs that you spend a fair amount of time waiting to heal before going to your next fight. You could remady that problem by using the command cheats some say but i have them and they don't seem to work. So it another 10 minuites for the HP gague to fill up.

Posted: February 1, 2014
												This game I picked up on a whim, and it turned out to be one of my, if not my absolute, favorite dungeon crawlers ever! The combat is visceral and has loads of impact and tons of play styles. Creature designs are interesting and varied. The loot system rains equipment upon you as frequently as the gore of your fallen foes.Graphically, for a 3/4 view dungeon crawler, this game looks fantastic! Character models are noticeably detailed and the environments look great. I'd say they are on par, and in some places, better than Diablo 3. Sound design is fantastic as well. The voice acting, while sometimes almost purposely cheesy, is very well done. The music, while not memorable, is not BAD. It just often gets drowned out by screaming and explosions. Story is decent as well. Not the games strong point, but no one plays dungeon crawlers for the story. However, I will say the story is significantly better than most I've played.Has several multi-player modes, but I haven't had the opportunity to play them, so I can't say how they are.The game has 2 glaring down sides, neither of them deal breaking:1 - I don't know if the game is optimized poorly, or what, but when you start the game, there is a very long pause, almost as if the game has frozen. There is no indication that anything is loading. After the first time it isn't an issue, but initially, it's jarring.2 - A similar problem happens with the loading screens. It takes quite a while for the loading "bar" to start to fill and the whole screen just reeks of "frozen game". I've nearly Alt+F4 many times because I assumed it had frozen.Only other bad thing I can think of is the game is pretty short. A max level cap of 30 and a 10 hour campaign feel prematurely ended. I wanted more of this game very badly, but for $15, I can't complain to much. I will definitely keep an eye out for Neocore games in the future

Posted: October 4, 2014
												Without a doubt, my favorite dungeon crawling game. Everything is done right. It has a linear story with slight control over a few things for the immersion factor. The UI is highly functional and easy to understand. The skill trees have no pitfalls and let you build the player as they want, yet it won't give you everything. On normal mode, it's a perfect balance between easy and hard, always providing a challenge. The characters are charming and offer a lot of humor. It has some easter eggs referencing Lord of the Rings and Monty Python, but does it in a way that won't make you shake your head in disappointment, like some other action RPGs.... *cough* BL2 *cough*. Even the achievements gave off of the right kind of vibe to where you feel actually accomplished by getting one, and have the motivation to get others. The art direction is fantastic, and the graphics look beautiful. Though, it's endorsed by NVIDIA, so it may not run as smoothly using AMD parts due to some sneaky hardware lock-outs. I'd recommend this game to anyone who loves Diablo or Victorian/Gothic fiction. You even get a spunky ghost sidekick

Posted: September 29, 2014
												Van Helsing is a great loot based game akin to Diablo, Torchlight and games such as those. Probably what makes it stand out is that the character you play, Van Helsing, has such a more engadging personality than most almost voiceless heroes of other similar games. There's some great chatter between him and his AI companion who is incredibly useful and easy to set up. In addition to this the people you meet are voiced well, over the top in so many ways and also fun to interact with (We are talking Vampires with the oh so wonderful Transylvanian accent.). Combat is about to be as expected. I've gone with a ranged firearm build. it works well and hits hard. But likle most ranged characters in this genre you are always limited to what you can see on the screen. So you usually only have a chance of having a real ranged battle with enemies in the top right and top left portions of the screen. Probably one of the best things when it comes to loot in this game is that you get an incredibly useful breakdown of how it will increase your stats. Unlike Torchlight II which I have also played recently, it does all the maths for you and will say how much your DPS will be improved for everything that increases damage in some way. i.e Damage, Extra Elemental Damage Bonuses, Critical Chance, Critical Damage, Attack speed, Stat increases and so on. The same goes for things like protection and so on. This means less time agonising over what new weapon or armour to equip (I'm looking at you Torchlight & Borderlands) and more time getting stuck into the action. The skill trees are straight forward as well and you can reset your stats in the game almost whenever you like back at the main hub.One of the biggest drawbacks of the game is that it frequently crashes. I've been playing for sometime now and have had over 50 crashes to my desktop. The majority of the crashes are usually when you teleport to a location or you accept a quest which automatically takes you to a new area as well. But there are a number of other minor causes as well. Automatic save points are frequent though so you never feel like you have been cheated out of a quest. But nevertheless it happens over and over again. Other things to mention are neat features like a Tower Defense game that pops up later into the game which is fun to play and simple management of upgrades for your main hubs and shops. This game also has multiplayer which I have yet to play but I have not heard great things about. I recently got a 50% off voucher for the next game in the series. So I am eager to pick it up once I have completed this one! Overall I recommend this game highly if you see it at a reasonable price and you enjoy the genre!

Posted: May 25, 2013
												Excellent game in the vein of Diablo I&II, Path of Exile, and Torchlight I&II.  Very smooth gameplay.  Patches have come out, and more are planned to take care of the kinks.  The skill trees are complex and offer a variety of options.  Your companion ghost adds to the humor with witty dialogue.  Her combat skills are also a great boon.  Drops are plentiful for weaponry, with a variety of pistols, rifles, and swords to hack, slash, and gib the enemies of humanity.  Each level offers a nice variety of monsters, and is crafted to give you a sense of being in another world where monsters are possible.  The many allusions to other games, movies, and novels add to the fun.  For the price, it's a steal of a game that you should enjoy. Grab a sword and pistol to complement your wide-brimmed hat and go slay some monsters!

Posted: February 7, 2015
												The incredible adventures of Van Helsing is a hack and slash type game and a very good one in my honest opinion. It does seem to be a bit heavy on the hardware side and to be fair it is not bad on the graphics side. It has a wide variety of skills to choose from, and where it really gets a plus from my side is the ability to choose between ranged and melee combat depending how you distribute your points. The game has a nice difficulty not too easy and not too hard and I quite enjoyed myself completing it. It does have multiplayer, which I have not tried out yet, but I could imagine it only gets more fun playing with friends.Story wise it is not perfect but it is all right and a nice gimmick is the tower defense based game you experience in the game.All in all a solid game that does what was intended and it has a buttload of DLC if you want expand on it.Buy it you will not regret it...

Posted: September 28, 2014
												To be honest, I got this game in a bundle and had no real intention to play it. On that note, I recently got a wired 360 controller again after trying to fiddle with an off-brand controller. After popping in the new controller, I wanted to quickly test it on a few games. This was one of the many that support the official xbox controller, and it worked great! What was going to be a quick five minutes of controller testing turned in to a couple hours of solid gameplay. I cannot speak for the mouse/keyboard feel of this game, but on controller, it is highly addicting. The art style and mood of this game really isn't over the top, but doesn't feel like crap, either. Comparing this to D3 would be futile as they feel like different games. From augmenting the several abilities and powers to the power interaction with your ghostly companion feels great. If you are looking for a game that is more skill-based instead gear-based, this would be a solid choice. If you'd love to sit back and play a decent rpg with multiple classes, get this with a controller. It looks nice and plays well. Really, those are the main two things I look for in a game.8/10

Posted: February 8, 2015
												I decided to play The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing after viewing the trailer, and getting some exhaustion from Diablo III and Torchlight 2. This one seemed to be a decent Hack & Slash, with a nice twist regarding the setting of central Europa and possibly legions of blood-sucking foes.In this game, you play a single character, Van Helsing, who is followed by a ghostly teammate, Katarina. You don't have to choose a class before playing, and just develop your character along the way, using several skill trees.Basically, you can eradicate a significant amount of monsters by using either a sword or a gun. Each weapon has its specific skill tree with numerous styles of slashes and shots. Each one can be leveled up, or customized with additional powers, triggered by Rage. Also, you can wander in the side of magic by learning strikes blending physical and magical damage, even pure magical damage. If not enough, you can learn passive abilities and active spells, that can take advantage of some specific situations or simply save your butt - leaving you with a fair amount of combinations to craft.The amount of damage you do or can endure is proportional to basic weapon and armor stats, plus the different levels of your character stats and skills, combined with the multiple bonuses you can get from gear. Very similar to Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2. So don't fall in love with that particular weapon or gear if the next one is seamingly up a notch, the impact could be tremendous.On top of that, your translucent female sidekick is not only witty, but can be used either as a melee fighter, a ranged shooter or a decent support. She also can level up and has her own gear and skill tree to become a tactical partner or a stat multiplier.At this point, it's pretty clear that this game targets an audience that loves to analyse how hundred skills relate to each other, carefully crafting the most badass character possible, something like "hit once, obliterate many". It's a good thing to have a significant amount of depth that way (remember Titan Quest !) but for me it was just like "too much". So I decided to focus on a restricted number of skills, low enough to keep me focused on the actual map cleaning.The game is linear, with some quests on the side. The levels are not really beautiful but varied, and the enemies compensate lack of intelligence by sheer number. Luckily, the dialog between Van Helsing and Katarina are funny so you can have a good time playing them.Something that kinda puzzled me was the introduction of a micro-game of Tower Defense. Not that it wasn't interesting or refreshing, but it seemed that the developers decided to put everything remotely cool in the game, thus pushing it in the Land of Blended Genre where chances of survival are slim. Luckily, the Tower Defense micro-game is nicely done, but too much thin for consideration. Overall, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a good Hack & Slash, that can satisfy seasoned players, but could be daunting to newcomers.

Posted: September 22, 2014
												I really wanted to love this game.  It has atmosphere, it has action and the vampire theme is great.  I did not go in expecting anything as that always sets up for disappointmen but after a bit of play I'm going to weigh in.  As I said, it is a very good looking game and fun to play as an isometric RPG.  I probably could have played it for a good long while but then the problems bleed through and they are, in my opinion, game breaking.  The main issue is that the load times are insane.  Time is precious and I don't want to sit there for minutes at a time waiting for an area to load.  This is excacerbated by the fact that you always have to start at a hub and then teleport to the area you want to be in.  That is two load screens too many.  Also, there is a really ridiculous death penalty.  You pay out of your character's coin purse to either start where you died or at the begining of the area.  If you want to save your coins you are sent to the hub.  More load screens!  My machine loads massive AAA titles in no time, so the problem is in the programming.  Anyways, I can't handle this stupid design so I'm ditching thi game.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												It's basically Torchlight.  Skill trees, HP and mana, a pet, color coded loot, etc. Some highlights:Skills have powerups you can enable per use that are fueled by a third resource called rage.  These do things like more damage, more targets, heal you on hit, and similar bonuses. You get rage when you kill monsters.  It's a nice little system I wouldn't mind seeing elsewhere.Easy respec on abilities and skills.  This was great for me when I realized investing heavily in the first skill wasn't a good long term solution, and when I realized one of my passives wasn't needed anymore.  You can also refund some of the starting skills if they aren't useful for you.   You can't respec perks for some reason, so check a guide before investing. Some of the late-game ones are straight out better than the early ones.Some meh-lights:The writing I found to be adequate.  Nothing exceptional, but it didn't pain me.  The core combat started out kind of bleh.  Slow, low damage attacks and limited mana.  It picked up after a little while, but the start wasn't great.  When I got the laser skill, it was just as fun as it was in Torchlight.I started to get some loot fatigue near the end.  There's a lot of items, and even with the summary tooltips it's sometimes hard to parse which item is really better.  One downer:A certain boss is one of the more frustrating bosses I've faced in a diablo-like.  He has a charge attack that could one-hit me, and he would do it from offscreen so I had no chance to dodge.  He also had homing missiles and infinite ranged attack mooks.  I did not enjoy that fight at all.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is one of the best ARPG I've ever played. Why? Let's start with the graphics. It looks beautiful. In my opinion, it's the best looking ARPG I've ever played. Finally some ARPG that overcome Titan Quest in this part. The soundtrack is also very good.I also like the enviroment. The game takes place in a country called Borgovia. It's similiar to the one you've seen in the original Van Helsing film. The nature and the village you will visit seems to be inspired by medieval Hungary and Romania. In most of the cases, the enemies you will face in the country will be monsters- wolves, spiders, but also Rusalka, a beast from Slavic myths. The situation will change once you enter the capital city, Borgova. The city contains more steampunk elements, e.g. robot soldiers or mutants, than the countryside. Some of the buildings there are inspired by buildings from our world. What I like the most about this games is the humour. In addition to the easter eggs, the dialogs between your character and Katarina are also well written and amusing. There is also a tower defence minigame. In this minigame, three waves of enemies would like to get into your base and you must stop them. In order to do that, you can put traps on the way to your lair. It can be a platform that will activate once an enemy will step on it. Or you can place various towers next to the path leading to your base. And of course, you and Katarina will also take place in preventing your enemies to get there.What I don't like very much is the fact that skills needs mana and they also have cooldown time after you've used them. I think it is not necessary. If you ask me, I believe that only one of those should be used. I would rather use only mana, like it is done in Torchlight. And also the fact that you can shoot enemies that are below or above you is not very good, in my opinion.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												Okay, yes, it's a Diablo clone.  And admittedly, it's not as good as the Torchlight games (get those if you haven't btw), but man are these games fun.  There are a lot of different methods of attack, lots of sarcasm, plenty of monster busting, and in general, it's just plain fun.  I really don't know what else to say.  I just plain love 'em.

Posted: December 31, 2014
												Mac support is a joke."Full controller support" is a blatant lie on OSX, since the devs themselves have said on the steam forums it has yet to be implemented. Same thing goes for the second instalment. I can't wrap my head around how you can release a second game without properly resolving **known** issues on the first one.And then there is also the thing about the UI scaling. All the UI is scaled down and the texts are almost impossible to read, making the game unplayable.I have been patient, asked for updates, stalked the support threads looking for any updates and posted my own issues there. Nothing.I'm still left with this game that I will have to play on Windows at some point. When the whole point was to play it with my wife on our macs.Sorry devs, you adverstised something and simply did not deliver.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												Acquired it with some bundle I don't recall now. Decided to try it since I've played Diablo 3 and Path of Exile a lot. Compared to free PoE it doesn't really stand a chance:comparatively short (HC normal 1st walkthrough - 12 hours)annoying controls - especially the way "walking" is handled: lots of "grey areas" aka "unclickables" resulting in botched kiting or even moving in the direction you intendeddifficulty level only scales up HP: no extra attacks for mobs, nothing special except larger HP poolskite or go to hell - died 3 times with melee, rerolled that mage class: set up firewall and run in circles, bosses includedgets boring super fast: each fight (bosses too) looked the same for me (firewall + circling)Overall if I bought this game "solo" I would be disappointed. If you want a hack n slash / aRPG - play Diablo 3 or Path of Exile. If you are a fan of Van Helsing, well - have fun I guess.

Posted: May 26, 2013
												Great game. Difficult to judge or compare.It's most frequently compared to Diablo and Torchlight, obviously. As it is a top-down  ARPG with Diablo-pioneered mechanics. I'd just try to point out the most striking qualities. (Oh, and when I say Diablo I mean 1 and 2. 3 doesn't exist for yours truly) In the setting, artwork and ambience it seems much closer to Diablo than Tordhlight.  Monsters, some grittyness et al et cetera. Yet Van Helsing tries its own in having more dialogue, and quite cheesy-yet-aware-of-it humorous based-in-vampire-themed-cultural-stuff style. In comparison to Torchlights it feels certainly more authentic and serious. Aside style, in the mechanics and stats-things. Yet it does fall a tad boring all in all.We arrive at a most apparent gripe, lack of stylistic variety. Whilst gameplay has the neatest ideas and mechanics, there's nothing really "wow" in Van Helsing's art direction and design. So aside some neat little mechanics, like trap-placing in Borgova, it doesn't feel too fresh or inspiring. So in the art, setting and overall originality department it's not as strong as was Diablo. And only a bit preferred over Torchlight. Yet it also falls short in a variety aspect that both Torchlight and Diablo have - classes. There isn't much replayablility and experimenting as there's only one character available for play, albeit with diverse and flexible specializing. Tho thanks to this, it does win some story and dialogue points over Torchlight. (since I wrote this, a DLC was made, now the game has 2 classes :)Torchlight, however, has a moddibility to it Van Helsing won't dream of achieving. Yet that's not as high in my hierarchy of idealized game aspects. :)All in all I'd give Van Helsing the same score as Torchlight 2. If objectively speaking. Personally I enjoy Helsing much much more tho. Plus I'd have to take into account that its starting price was 10 euros. There's vast quality for such a small price.So I'll compromise between the two and write it an 8 in a scoring system where Torchlight 2 would get a 7,5.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												Many would call it another Diablo clone, but for me its just another action RPG/Hack'n Slay type of game which is on the better side of the genre. It is always hard to find games in this genre which manage to keep the balance between challanging and fun and in my opionion Van Hellsing does a good job in this regard. The gameplay is fun and at times really challenging (or at least at the harder dificulties, havn't tried the lower modes yet) and you are always on the lookout for better equimpent.One thing i really liked about the game was the fact that it mixed in a the genre of tower defense at one point which was really really fun and I would have loved to see more of this in the game, or at least as a standlone challange mode or something.The Graphics are not great or groundbreaking, but hey neither is the gameplay, but it provides a nice atmosphere one would expect from a set in the Van Helsing univers. The few things I would critzize are the lack of enemy variaties, you encounter some enimies over and over again and again, and the companion, while you she provides a nice sidekick and humour i couldn't figer out if she was usefull or not (I don't own the DLC). Oh and the Story is, in like most of these games, flat and forseeable but better than some other things that I've seen in this genre. But really who plays a game like this for the story...I don't.Overall I recommend this game to all fans of the genre who need something else besides the to heabyweights Diablo and Torchlight

Posted: December 26, 2013
												So much more fun than I ever expected!

Posted: June 14, 2013
												Van Helsing sits in an odd gray area in the Diablolike genre. It's not as in depth as Diablo II, it's not as expansive as Sacred II, you don't have nearly as much build flexibility as Titan Quest, your companion isn't as relevant as it is in Torchlight II, the action isn't as fast and furious as Diablo III, and the systems in general aren't as deep and flexible as Path of Exile.If you're looking for one or more of the above, get any of those games instead. If you've played them all, or just like the Van Helsing mythos, it's worth it if on sale. Van Helsing tends to focus more on the story than most Diablolikes. The banter between your character and your companion is worth listening to; it's worth following the storyline and talking to NPCs. The setting is charming and unique. It just doesn't execute as well as other games.Oh, and you get one class to play. The other two are DLC.

This is the kind of bug that grows old fast and therefore I suggest you stay away from buying this game (unless it gets patched).

Posted: August 11, 2013
												A legitimately fresh look at the genre, with all the upsides of recent advancements and few of the flaws. Skills are varied and scalable, and can be modded on the fly to whole new ends. Passives are valuable, abilities easy to use, weapons fresh and fun. Your companion is equippable, has her own skills and passives, and has an AI you can customize to any style. Combat can be difficult, not fake difficult but truly hard. And the visuals and audio are good... Although the music can get slightly repetitive. All in all, one of my favorite new games of 2013, especially at this price point.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												I got this over Halloween during one of the sales.  I have to admit for the money it is a beautiful game.   A great feel to it, I loved the atmosphere and the whole feel to it.  They did a great job.  I found myself buying a bit of the DLC and playing a few of the additional characters, and some of the extra content after you finish the story line.I have to admit that my major complaint is that I wish there was more of it!  I loved it, and wanted to keep playing.  I hope they continue to expand this game, which I believe they could.  If you liked Torchlight and Torchlight 2, this is a must have for you.  The minion dynamic and game feel is very similar, but she is a lot more fun than a dog.  I tend to play my games with the sound off, but found myself turning it on so I could hear her banter.A definite fun game, well worth the money.

Posted: November 4, 2013
												I have played PoE Beta, Torchlight 1 & 2, Diablo 1, 2 and 3. This game beats them all except for maybe Diablo 2 with Expansion during its heyday. Van Helsing is fun and unique with witty dialogue and snappy writing. You actually get rewarded for exploring your entire map. The loot is fun (no AH). You can play offline if it's just single player. You can also play online (public or steam friends only) with up to 4 people in co-op (password or sans). Your companion picks up stuff like potions, crafting mats and different levels of unique or common gear depending on how you set her. She can also be sent to town to sell, as well as buy a specifically designated number of potions; She's sassy too. You have enchanting as well as alchemy for upgrading your gear. You make decisions in dialogue even that impact your gameplay more true to table-top role playing games! Yes, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is addictive and yes, the story is fun. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys top-down action rpgs. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is what Diablo 3 should have been.[ Also, I just go the DLC tonight and I am enjoying my Arcane Mechanic, which can be played with pets. I have yet to try the Thaumargist (sp?), which appears to be a steampunk version of a mage. I do like the steampunkish feel of hte game. The artwork is quite good. ]

Posted: January 24, 2014
												Rate: Highly recommended. Pros: action, graphics, sound, music, characters, gameplay, combat, style & approach, atmosphereSolid: length, has replayability value, Cons: plotPerks: high octane hack n' slash, inventive gameplay (though still far from Path of Exile), original style.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												A really immersive RPG comined with fun combat mechanics and an amazing talent tree customization.I am only 5 hours in at the time of writing this review, and I was completely glued to my seat from the start. The quests are quite interesting and the dialogues exchanged between the Van Helsing's son and his ghost-sidekick Lady Katarina are hilarious at most times.Overall this game proves to be a very competent RPG so far, and the mobs and bosses can be very taxing if not handled properly. I would definitely recommend this game to every RPG fan out there.

Posted: January 19, 2014
												A great game for hardcore dungeon crawlers. It requires you to masterize a complex set of abilities and skills and get a deep understaning of their benefits and usage. It takes time, but you can fully configure your character to make it fit your gaming style and strategy. I've played it with a friend in coop, from start to end, and we decided to specialize in complementary abilities to get an edge in battle. It was really fun, specially in the Tower Defense sections. If you are a Diablo3 lover, get this one, it won't disappoint you.
